revision.text:
[[File:5Rhythms Logo.jpg|thumb|right|The 5Rhythms logo]]
'''5Rhythms'''<ref group=uspto>USPTO registration #  '''3157101'''http://tmsearch.uspto.gov/European Union Registration #''' 005669874'''https://euipo.europa.eu/eSearch/#details/trademarks/005669874 </ref> is a movement meditation practice devised by [[Gabrielle Roth]] in the late 1970s.<ref>{{cite web|last=North|first=Madelaine|title=TALK OF THE TOWN: Just do it Rhythm is a dancer |work=Independent on Sunday|url=http://findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_qn4159/is_20050220/ai_n9771257|date=20 February 2005}}</ref> It draws from indigenous and world traditions using tenets of [[shamanism|shamanistic]], [[ecstatic dance|ecstatic]], mystical and [[eastern philosophy]]. It also draws from [[Gestalt therapy]], the human potential movement and [[transpersonal psychology]]. Fundamental to the practice is the idea that everything is energy, and moves in waves, [[Patterns in nature|patterns]] and rhythms.
Roth describes the practice as a soul journey, and says that by moving the body, releasing the heart, and freeing the mind, one can connect to the essence of the soul, the source of inspiration in which an individual has unlimited possibility and potential.
==The practice== The practice of the 5Rhythms is said by [[Gabrielle Roth]] to put the body in motion in order to still the mind. The five rhythms (in order) are Flowing, Staccato, Chaos, Lyrical and Stillness.<ref group=uspto>USPTO Registration #''' 4840073''' European Union (https://euipo.europa.eu/eSearch/) Registration # '''014276281'''</ref> The 5Rhythms, when danced in sequence, are known as a "Wave." A typical Wave takes about an hour to dance.<ref>Gabrielle Roth. ''Maps to Ecstasy'', 1989.</ref>
Longer workshops may, according to ''The Dancing Path'', explore emotion, the cycle of life, the ego, relationships and spiritual vision.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.gabrielleroth.com/ |work=5 rhythms global |title=The Dancing Path |accessdate=28 January 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120912075641/http://www.gabrielleroth.com/ |archivedate=12 September 2012 |df= }}</ref>
==The 5Rhythms Maps==
The work is taught through a series of maps that explore the terrain of the inner and outer worlds of individuals, their relationships to others and the space around them. The maps offer a soul journey by exploring embodiment, emotions, the life cycle, the psyche, and the archetypes. The rhythms offer understanding of people's innate powers – being, loving, knowing, seeing and healing.<ref name="Maps">{{cite web |title=The Maps of the 5Rhythms |url=https://www.5rhythms.com/gabrielle-roths-5rhythms/workshops/ |publisher=5Rhythms |accessdate=18 October 2018}}</ref>
The first map, "Waves" teaches embodiment of the five distinct rhythms. To embody the rhythms means to access the deep internal wisdom that human bodies contain. The "Heartbeat" map teaches how people have embodied and how they express the emotions of fear, anger, sadness, joy and compassion; while the "Cycles" map provides insight and understanding about how one has internalized conditioning and relationships throughout the life cycle, specifically in the stages of birth, childhood, puberty, maturity and death. Insight and understanding of the ego is delivered through the psyche map, "Mirrors".<ref name="Maps"/>
Roth drew a circular "Medicine Mandala" that related each rhythm to an emotion, a stage of life, a way of perceiving, and an aspect of the self.<ref name="Mandala">{{cite web |title=Gabrielle Roth's 5Rhythms |url=https://www.5rhythms.com/gabrielle-roths-5rhythms/ |publisher=5Rhythms |accessdate=18 October 2018}}</ref>
{| class="wikitable" |+ style="text-align: center;" | The elements of [[Gabrielle Roth]]'s "Medicine Mandala"<ref name="Mandala"/> |- ! [[Rhythm]] !! [[Emotion]] !! Stage of life !! Way of perceiving !! Aspect of self |- | Flowing || [[Fear]] || [[Birth]] || Being || Body |- | Staccato || [[Anger]] || [[Childhood]] || Loving || Heart |- | Chaos || [[Sadness]] || [[Puberty]] || Knowing || [[Mind]] |- | Lyrical || [[Joy]] || [[Maturity (psychological)|Maturity]] || Seeing || [[Soul]] |- | Stillness || [[Compassion]] || [[Death]] || Healing || [[Spirit]] |}
==Schools and teachers== Roth founded ''The Moving Center''<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.5rhythms.com/the-moving-center-new-york/|title=The Moving Center NY|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> in New York in 1977 as a base for her workshops, and to train and develop teachers.<ref>[http://www.5rhythms.com/the-moving-center-new-york/ 5Rhythms: Moving Center New York]. Retrieved February 4, 2014</ref> ''5Rhythms Global'' <ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.5rhythms.com/who-we-are/5rhythms-global/|title=5Rhythms Global|last=|first=|date=|website=5Rhythms.com|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> was founded in 2013 as the international Institute training 5Rhythms teachers worldwide. The [[5Rhythms Teachers Association]]<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.5rhythms.com/who-we-are/5rhythms-teachers-association/|title=5Rhythms Teachers Association|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> was founded in 2007 as a professional association serving the continuing education of accredited 5Rhythms teachers. The 5Rhythms movement spread worldwide, and in 2017 there were 396 certified teachers and SpaceHolders<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.5rhythms.com/5rhythms-sweat-spaceholder-program/|title=5Rhythms {{!}} 5Rhythms Sweat SpaceHolder Program|work=5Rhythms {{!}} 5Rhythms Sweat SpaceHolder Program|access-date=2017-07-14|language=en-US}}</ref> in 50+ countries.<ref name="5Rhythms Global, Find A Teacher">{{cite web|title=Find A Teacher|url=http://www.5rhythms.com/TeacherSearch.php|website=5Rhythms Global|accessdate=16 October 2016}}</ref> 5Rhythms also forms part of the Open Floor movement practice designed by Andrea Juhan.<ref>{{cite web |title=Frequently Asked Questions |url=https://openfloor.org/about-us/faq |publisher=OpenFloor International |accessdate=30 July 2018}}</ref>
==Reception==
Charlotte Macleod, writing in the ''[[London Evening Standard]]'' in 2009, describes dancing the 5Rhythms as a kind of antidote to life in a large city, and how she was attracted to a dance class by a video of Thom Yorke. The class leaves her "mentally and physically refreshed, and oddly connected to the other dancers." The dance was "a kind of moving meditation" for her.<ref name="EveningStandard">{{cite web | url=http://www.thisislondon.co.uk/lifestyle/thom-yorke-and-the-new-5rhythms-dance-craze-6389419.html | title=Thom Yorke and the new 5Rhythms dance craze | work=London Evening Standard | date=April 6, 2011 | accessdate=March 17, 2012 | author=Macleod, Charlotte}}</ref>
Christine Ottery, writing in ''[[The Guardian]]'' in 2011, states that "ecstatic dancing has an image problem" and "encompasses everything from large global movements such as 5Rhythms and [[Biodanza]] to local drum'n'dance meet-ups". She suggests that readers may "find 5 Rhythms a good place to start", and does so herself: "Nervously, I stretch and warm my muscles. As the rhythms take off, I shake off my shyness." She dances in different ways, alone or with partners. "My body is expressing itself - it's utter abandonment and a complete high."<ref name="Guardian">{{cite web | url=https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2009/jul/21/ecstatic-dance?INTCMP=SRCH | title=Ecstatic dance: rhythm to beat the blues | work=The Guardian | date=21 July 2009 | accessdate=March 18, 2012 | author=Ottery, Christine}}</ref>
Jed Lipinski, writing in ''[[The New York Times]]'' in 2010, notes that 5Rhythms is suitable for all ages, unlike some other forms of dance and movement. He observes that "At a recent 5Rhythms class ... in Manhattan, more than 100 people were gleefully writhing and leaping to tribal drumming courtesy of Ms. Roth's husband, Robert Ansell... Dancers occasionally released guttural howls, as if exorcising the demons of the workweek."<ref name="NYT">{{cite news | url=https://www.nytimes.com/2010/08/05/fashion/05Sober.html?_r=1 | work=The New York Times | department= Fashion and Style | title=Dance, Dance, Dance. And That's It. | date=4 August 2010 | accessdate=9 June 2012 | author=Lipinski, Jed}}</ref>
''[[The Daily Telegraph]]'' writes of 5Rhythms in 2007 that "I love it precisely because it isn't based on learned steps. Instead, the idea is to find your own dance by moving your body in whatever way you fancy. For those of us keen to improve our fitness, it can also be an energetic aerobic workout."<ref name=Telegraph>{{cite web | url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/health/3346805/Feel-the-rhythm-from-head-to-heal.html | title=Feel the rhythm from head to heal | author=unattributed | publisher=Telegraph.co.uk | date=6 January 2007 | accessdate=1 July 2012}}</ref>
==Research== Academics working in mental health and other fields are starting to carry out research about the 5Rhythms. The [[Mental Health Foundation]], a UK charity published the 'Dancing for Living Report' describing a group of women's experience of 5Rhythms dance and the effects on their emotional wellbeing.<ref>{{Citation | last=Cook | first=Sarah | last2=Ledger | first2=Karen | last3=Scott | first3=Nadine | author-link= | year=2003 | title=Dancing for Living Report: Women's experience of 5 Rhythms dance and the effects on their emotional wellbeing | publication-place=Sheffield | publisher=UK Advocacy Network | url=http://www.mentalhealth.org.uk/publications/dancing-for-a-living/}}</ref> The 5Rhythms have been the subject of a number of PhD theses.<ref name="WorldCat Listing of Andrea Juhan's Thesis">{{cite web|title=WorldCat Listing of Andrea Juhan's Thesis|url=http://www.worldcat.org/title/open-floor-dance-therapy-and-transformation-through-the-5rhythms/oclc/60710012|website=WorldCat Listing|accessdate=16 October 2016}}</ref><ref name=Hogya>{{cite web | url=http://boldgirldance.com/wp-content/uploads/2010/07/Anne-Marie-Hogya-5Rhythms-Selected-Thesis-Chapters-May-16-.pdf | title=5RHYTHMS™ IN THE WORKPLACE: EXPLORING MOVEMENT AS A CORPORATE TRAINING APPROACH | publisher=Royal Roads University | date=March 2004 | accessdate=March 17, 2012 | author=Hogya, Anne Marie}}</ref>
==Parody in popular culture== The British TV sitcom ''[[Peep Show (TV series)|Peep Show]]'' featured an episode ("Dance Class") where the two principal male characters attend a 'Rainbow Rhythms' class which invites its participants to interpretatively dance 'colours', featuring guidance and a closing circle reminiscent of a 5Rhythms class.
== See also == * [[Ecstatic dance]] * [[Biodanza]] * [[Movement Medicine]] * [[Sacred dance]]

revision.text:
'''Aesthetic judgement''', often also referred to as ‘taste’, is a concept in [[aesthetics]] which attempts to explain the nature of judgements of [[beauty]] and whether or not these judgements are legitimate.
The key idea for most traditional theories of taste was that objects possessed concrete properties that the perceiver ought to judge as beautiful or not. Failure to make the correct judgement was considered as something deficient within the beholder, whether that be a flaw within the person’s virtue or connected to a lack of knowledge that hinders their ability to perceive the beauty of the object.
Aesthetic judgement as a concept rose to prominence in the eighteenth century, however its roots can be traced back many years to ancient Greek and medieval philosophers.
== Ancient conceptions of aesthetic judgement == [[File:Sanzio 01 Plato Aristotle.jpg|thumb|The central image from Raphael's ''[[The School of Athens]]'' (1509-1511), depicting Plato (left) and Aristotle (right). Plato is depicted pointing upwards, in reference to his theory of forms, whilst Aristotle disagrees and points down towards reality, in reference to his belief in [[empiricism]].]] [[Ancient Greek philosophy|Ancient Greek philosophers]] did not possess an explicit concept of aesthetic judgement, however their ideas regarding aesthetics inspired later developments.
=== Plato === [[Plato|Plato’s]] [[Metaphysics|metaphysical]] theory held that there is an incorporeal realm in which the perfect [[Theory of forms|Forms]] of reality exist. This includes the perfect Form of Beauty, which one can rise up to through a [[Dialectic|dialectical]] method. Thus, in Plato’s terms, knowledge is critical to developing a better understanding of beauty and thus, a better capacity for aesthetic judgement.<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=https://www.iep.utm.edu/a-taste/|title=Aesthetic Taste|last=Spicher|first=Michael|date=|website=Internet Encyclopedia of Philosophy|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2 November 2018}}</ref>
=== Aristotle === [[Aristotle]] purported a more [[Experiential knowledge|experiential]] approach to aesthetic judgement, in that beauty was a property of objects being related to their size and proportion. To develop a capacity for aesthetic judgement, one has to observe enough objects of the same kind to uncover the correct form of those things. Both Aristotle and Plato perceived beauty as a property existing outside of human experience, with aesthetic judgement being the capacity to recognise that beauty, developed by the search for beauty in things.<ref name=":0" />
== Medieval conceptions of aesthetic judgement == Although Medieval philosophers did not possess a particular notion of individual preference or taste, they were particularly preoccupied with a [[Cosmology|cosmological]] interpretation of beauty, with relation to specific [[Ontology|ontological]] properties. This is attributed to the fact that philosophers of the medieval age had an object notion of beauty, and also because it was a common belief that morality was linked with beauty.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Marinescu|first=Axia|date=2014-01-01|title=Beauty and Judgement in German Aesthetics|url=https://content.sciendo.com/view/journals/hssr/3/1/article-p124.xml|journal=Human & Social Studies. Research and Practice|language=en|volume=3|issue=1|doi=10.2478/hssr-2013-0024|issn=2285-5920}}</ref>
=== Augustine of Hippo === Expanding upon Plato’s Theory of the Forms, [[Augustine of Hippo|Augustine]] believed that perfect beauty existed within God. Augustine proposed equality and unity as the two properties that made physical objects beautiful. Aesthetic judgement is thus the ability of an individual to recognise the unity and equality of an object, thus involving an exercise of reason and knowledge, similar to the theories of previous thinkers.<ref name=":0" /> Since the ultimate state of beauty exists in God’s mind, an observer can only recognise this through [[divine illumination]]. Thus, one’s capacity for aesthetic judgement is improved the closer one is to God.
=== Thomas Aquinas === [[Thomas Aquinas|Aquinas]] also presented properties that make an object beautiful: proportion, wholeness and radiance. Thus, similar to his philosophical predecessors, he constituted the judgement of beauty to be dependent on knowledge and occurring through the function of cognition. Possessing a capacity for aesthetic judgement is therefore determined by one’s ability to recognise these properties in observed objects. Aquinas does however diverge from previous philosophers on certain notions. His definition of that beauty as "that which, when seen, pleases" can be interpreted as an implication of the subjectivity of beauty and thus judgements about it.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Wood|first=Robert E.|date=2015-06-23|title=Review of Aquinas on Beauty|url=https://ndpr.nd.edu/news/aquinas-on-beauty/|issn=1538-1617}}</ref> Furthermore, he rejects Plato’s Theory of Forms, stating that beauty is a real quality present within objects. Ultimately however he converges upon Augustine’s view that God is the source of all beauty.<ref name=":0" />
== 18th century theories of aesthetic judgement == Explicit theories of aesthetic judgement emerged and predominated in the 18<sup>th</sup> century, being referred to as “the century of taste”.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/435824318|title=The century of taste : the philosophical odyssey of taste in the eighteenth century|last=1926-|first=Dickie, George,|date=1996|publisher=Oxford University Press|isbn=9780195357134|location=New York|oclc=435824318}}</ref> Philosophers developed a more introspective stance to attempt to understand their personal dispositions to beauty.
=== Anthony Cooper, the Third Earl of Shaftesbury === [[Anthony Ashley-Cooper, 3rd Earl of Shaftesbury|Anthony Cooper]] (1671-1713), the Third Earl of Shaftesbury, purported his philosophical ideas through his [[Socratic dialogue]] “The Moralists, a Philosophical Rhapsody”, which stands in almost direct contrast to the theories and assumptions posited by Addison.<ref name=":1">{{Citation|last=Shelley|first=James|title=18th Century British Aesthetics|date=2018|url=https://plato.stanford.edu/archives/fall2018/entries/aesthetics-18th-british/|work=The Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy|editor-last=Zalta|editor-first=Edward N.|edition=Fall 2018|publisher=Metaphysics Research Lab, Stanford University|access-date=2018-11-02}}</ref> Shaftesbury claimed that taste was a quality innate within human beings. One’s capacity to observe and make correct judgements of beauty was dependent on one’s moral righteousness. The key property Shaftesbury ascribed to beautiful objects is harmony, the prime source of which is nature, which in turn is formed by God who is constituted as the ultimate source of beauty.
=== Joseph Addison === [[Joseph Addison]] (1672-1719) posited theories that were in almost direct contrast to those of Shaftesbury. Central to Addison’s theory of aesthetic judgement is the concept that pleasures of taste are essentially “pleasures of the imagination”.<ref name=":1" /> Addison’s fundamental divergence from Shaftesbury is that he views taste to be a judgement of visual representation as exercised by the imagination, rather than as an exercise of the intellect and of moral righteousness. Addison constituted two types of pleasures of the imagination: primary pleasures, as in those derived from visual images directly observed by an individual of an object in front of them and secondary pleasures, which arise from images of objects that are absent from sight and therefore exist only in the mind. Addison’s materialist basis predisposes his theory to subjectivism and relativism, leading Addison to declare that there “is not perhaps any real beauty”.<ref name=":1" />
=== Alexander Gerard === [[Alexander Gerard]] (1728-1795) considered taste in a similar fashion to the six external [[Sense|senses]], in that experiences of aesthetic judgement are also simple and instantaneous. He also developed his views from the philosophical framework of [[associationism]]. Aesthetic judgements are exercises of the faculty of imagination, in which a newly observed object is associated to previous ideas in the mind of the observer.<ref name=":0" /> Gerard determines that taste is improved when a person exercises their capacities for judgment and taste to recognise the four core elements of sensibility, refinement, correctness and proportion within objects.
== David Hume's theory of taste == David Hume’s theories on aesthetic judgement were purported in his 1757 essay ''[[Four Dissertations|Of the Standard of Taste]]''. Hume ascribed some normative quality to aesthetic judgements whilst providing critiques of the more relativist positions on the matter. Whilst acknowledging that judgements cannot reasonably be determined to be objectively true or false, he championed the notion of “common sense”, which held that some evaluations are better than others.<ref name=":2">{{Cite web|url=http://web.mnstate.edu/gracyk/courses/phil%20of%20art/hume_and_kant.htm|title=Aesthetic theories of David Hume and Immanuel Kant|website=web.mnstate.edu|access-date=2018-11-02}}</ref> Hume also reinforced the conception of aesthetic judgements as an exercise of the faculty of the imagination, determining beauty to not be a property of objects but existing only in the mind, and the ones that are deemed more beautiful are the ones that affect the higher sentiments, or high cognitive or intellectual capacities of the observer. Hume also sought to establish a universal standard of aesthetic judgement, seeking a basis upon which we can “confirm” one sentiment and “condemn” another.<ref name=":2" /> In doing this he refers to [[Classic book|classic texts]] which seemingly have received universal acclaim beyond through different times and cultures. Hume asserts that such universal acclamation identifies a work of real genius, and such works should be examined to provide us with guidelines for the composition of good art. Hume provides characteristics of what he refers to as a true judge in matters of aesthetics: [[File:Painting of David Hume.jpg|thumb|''Portrait of David Hume'' ''(1711-1776)'']] {{Quote|text="Strong sense, united to delicate sentiment, improved by practice, perfected by comparison, and cleared of all prejudice”|sign=David Hume|source="Four Dissertations", Of the Standard of Taste}}The consensus of these critics constitutes what Hume called a “joint verdict”<ref name=":3">{{Cite web|url=https://www.encyclopedia.com/humanities/encyclopedias-almanacs-transcripts-and-maps/aesthetic-judgment|title=Aesthetic Judgment {{!}} Encyclopedia.com|website=www.encyclopedia.com|language=en|access-date=2018-11-02}}</ref>, which composes the "true standard"<ref name=":2" /> for aesthetic judgements. This standard is constituted as universally correct, and failure to recognise pleasure in the object is considered a defect within the observer.
Hume does concede however that certain subjectivities affecting aesthetic judgements cannot be eliminated. He indicates two circumstances that will create irrevocable prejudices. First he refers to natural, generational and cultural dispositions which are fundamental and relative to individuals. The second is determined by the critics’ degree of moral righteousness. Ascribing a normative characteristic to morality, Hume declares that aesthetic merit is influenced by “the natural boundaries of vice and virtue”<ref name=":2" />, and if the artist does not conform to these moral regulations then they and their art will inevitably divert from Hume’s true standard.
== Immanuel Kant's "judgement of taste" == Central to the concept of aesthetic judgement is Kant’s notion of the “judgement of taste”, introduced in his seminal 1790 book the ''[[Critique of Judgment|Critique of Judgement]].'' In the text, Kant determined two essential conditions for a judgement to be classified as a judgement of taste – subjectivity and universality.
Subjectivity refers to the fact that a judgement of taste is based on a feeling of pleasure or displeasure. The second necessary condition of a judgement of taste is that it claims “universal validity”, which Kant describes as follows:
{{Quote|text=“… when [a man] puts a thing on a pedestal and calls it beautiful, he demands the same delight from others. He judges not merely from himself, but for all men, and then speaks of beauty as if it were a property of things”|sign=Immanuel Kant|source=Critique of Judgement}} Kant emphasises the fact that requiring the agreement of others is an inextricable characteristic of aesthetic judgements. We think that others “ought” to share our judgement, and we blame them if they don’t, as if there was a deficiency within them to recognise beauty and make judgements upon it.<ref>{{Citation|last=Zangwill|first=Nick|title=Aesthetic Judgment|date=2014|url=https://plato.stanford.edu/archives/fall2014/entries/aesthetic-judgment/|work=The Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy|editor-last=Zalta|editor-first=Edward N.|edition=Fall 2014|publisher=Metaphysics Research Lab, Stanford University|access-date=2018-11-02}}</ref> Aesthetic judgements, unique from other types of judgements that Kant lists, therefore make a claim to universal validity. Kant also states that pleasure in beauty is disinterested in that it is desire-free. Whilst agreeing that pleasure in beauty can generate desire, he states that it is an essential characteristic of aesthetic judgements that they are found to be pleasurable because they are judged to be beautiful, rather than being judged as beautiful because they are found to be pleasurable.<ref name=":4">{{Cite web|url=https://www.iep.utm.edu/kantaest/#SH2a|title=Immanuel Kant: Aesthetics|last=Burnham|first=Douglas|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2 November 2018}}</ref>
Kant provides a “deep” account of the nature of pleasure in beauty, which states that it accomplished through the simultaneous exercise of the cognitive faculties of imagination and understanding.<ref name=":4" /> This is the premise upon which Kant asserts his normative claim on aesthetic judgements. Because these judgements are a function of cognitive faculties, which Kant assumed can be shared by humans, it must be possible for them to be shared. Kant also purported that pleasure in beauty can be attributed to our recognition that the qualities of an object conform to basic functions of human cognition. We maintain a presupposition that all objects seemed to be formed in a way that enables them to be analysed by human observers. Beauty is the quality of an object assuming a “form of purposiveness”, despite the absence of an identification of a specific purpose.<ref name=":2" /> When we respond to an object’s appearance without any comprehension of utility, we respond in an aesthetic manner. The feeling of pleasure is a signal that the object is able to be comprehended through exercising the human faculty of understanding. An aesthetic judgement is therefore a judgement about human cognition rather than a material object.
== Nineteenth and twentieth century theories of aesthetic judgement == Philosophical concerns with aesthetic judgement declined rapidly after the 19<sup>th</sup> century, with the majority of discourse shifting to the concept of an aesthetic attitude.<ref name=":0" /> Despite this, there have been philosophers who have persisted with the concept of aesthetic taste, which has resulted in some notable contributions in contemporary times.
=== Frank Sibley === [[Frank Sibley (philosopher)|Frank Sibley]] (1929-1996) defined aesthetic judgements to be evaluations that apply aesthetic concepts to objects through aesthetic terminology. Taste is thus an individual’s capacity to recognise these properties and employ aesthetic concepts and terms appropriately to describe them.<ref name=":3" /> Sibley also asserts that aesthetic judgements are objective and that beauty is an objective property present within objects, departing from the 18<sup>th</sup> century philosophical norm of subjectivist interpretation.
== References ==
[[Category:Aesthetics]]

{{Infobox film | name = Ali: Fear Eats the Soul | image = Alifeareats.jpg | alt = | caption = German theatrical release poster | film name = <!-- {{Infobox name module|language|title}} or {{Infobox name module|title}} --> | director = [[Rainer Werner Fassbinder]] | producer = Rainer Werner Fassbinder<ref name="filmportal.de" /> | writer = | screenplay = Rainer Werner Fassbinder<ref name="filmportal.de" /> | story = | based on = <!-- {{Based on|title of the original work|creator of the original work|additional creator(s), if necessary}} --> | starring = {{plainlist|* [[Brigitte Mira]] * [[El Hedi ben Salem]] * [[Barbara Valentin]] * [[Irm Hermann]]}} | narrator = | music = | cinematography = Jürgen Jürges<ref name="filmportal.de" /> | editing = Thea Eymèsz<ref name="filmportal.de" /> | studio = Tango-Film<ref name="filmportal.de" /> | distributor = Filmverlag der Autoren GmbH & Co. Vertriebs KG<ref name="filmportal.de" /> | released = {{Film date|df=yes|1974|3|5|West Germany}} | runtime = 93 minutes<ref name="filmportal.de" /> | country = West Germany<ref name="filmportal.de" /> | language = | budget = | gross = }}
'''''Ali: Fear Eats the Soul''''' ({{lang-de|'''Angst essen Seele auf'''|lit=Fear Eat Soul Up}}) is a 1974 [[West German film]] written and directed by [[Rainer Werner Fassbinder]], starring [[Brigitte Mira]] and [[El Hedi ben Salem]]. The film won the [[International Federation of Film Critics]] award for best in-competition movie and the [[Prize of the Ecumenical Jury]] at the [[1974 Cannes Film Festival]].<ref name="festival-cannes.com">{{cite web |url=http://www.festival-cannes.com/en/archives/ficheFilm/id/2216/year/1974.html |title=Festival de Cannes: ''Ali: Fear Eats the Soul'' |accessdate=2009-04-26|work=festival-cannes.com}}</ref> It is considered to be one of Fassbinder's most powerful works and is hailed by many as a masterpiece.
The film revolves around the romance that develops between Emmi, an elderly German woman and Ali, a Moroccan migrant worker in post-[[World War II]] [[Germany]].
==Plot== The film takes place an unspecified number of months after the [[Munich Massacre]] in [[West Germany]]. Emmi (Mira), a 60 year-old window cleaner and widow, enters a bar, driven in by the rain and wanting to listen to the music being played inside. A woman in the bar (Katharina Herberg) tauntingly suggests Ali (Salem), a [[Morocco|Moroccan]] ''[[Gastarbeiter]]'' ([[guest worker]]) in his late thirties, ask Emmi to dance, to which Emmi accepts. After they dance, they develop a friendship and Ali follows Emmi home, staying at her apartment for the night. After some more interaction between the two, they start to fall in love and Ali continues to live with Emmi. Emmi decides to visit her children to introduce them to Ali; daughter Krista ([[Irm Hermann]]) and her tyrannical son-in-law Eugen (Fassbinder himself); Eugen thinks she is losing her sanity and Krista thinks that her mother - who has been a widow for years - is fantasizing.
Their relationship is threatened when the landlord's son, who has been sent on the assumption that Emmi has taken in a lodger, to point out to Emmi that subletting is against Emmi's tenancy agreement, and that Ali must leave within a day. Fearful of losing Ali, Emmi claims that she and Ali are planning to marry to alleviate this problem. After the landlord's son apologizes for the misapprehension and leaves, Emmi speaks to Ali and apologizes for having invented the idea of her marrying him, but is surprised by Ali when he says that it is an excellent idea. The film then shows them in a civil court, married.
Their marriage is looked upon negatively by those who live near them, which include apartment tenants and nearby shop keepers. Emmi is shunned by her coworkers, and Ali faces discrimination at every turn. When Emmi invites her three grown children and son-in-law to meet Ali, they openly reject him. One of Emmi's sons smashes in her TV set in anger, her other son declares she must have lost her sanity, and her daughter calls her apartment a "pigsty" and calls Emmi a "whore", before the four of them leave.
Emmi's sadness towards this rejection washes away as her optimism resurfaces and decides that she and Ali should take a long vacation together to escape the discrimination, convinced that upon return, they will have been missed and will be welcomed back. After their return, they face less discrimination, but only because neighboring tenants and shopkeepers see the gain in treating Emmi better, not because they have outgrown their prejudices.
Wanting to get back with her old friends' after their apparent renewed respect, Emmi begins to neglect Ali or to adopt some of their attitudes toward him. She becomes more strict, ordering him to do more things. When co-workers visit and remark on how surprisingly clean he is and comment on his muscles, she shows him off as if he were an object. This causes Ali to leave, and to seek comfort in female bartender Barbara (Barbara Valentin), with whom he has apparently had a relationship with prior to meeting Emmi. When he leaves Emmi to her friends, she attributes it to his "mood swings," and notes that it must be his "foreigner mentality", adopting the xenophobic attitudes of her friends in order to fit in. This causes them to drift apart, with Ali not standing up to Emmi because of the insecurities he faces as a foreigner. He then turns back to the bartender, spending the night with her. Emmi wants to see him more visits him at work, where he pretends he doesn't know her as his workmates make fun of her age, calling her Ali's "Moroccan grandmother."
Just when it seems as if the relationship is beyond repair, Emmi goes back to the bar where they first met to meet with Ali and has the bartender put the same song on the jukebox that led to their dance in the beginning of the movie. They decide to dance together, and, while dancing, Emmi emphasizes that she knows she is old and that he is free to come and go, but tells him that when they are together, they must be nice to each other. He agrees and they declare their love for each other. In that moment, Ali collapses in Emmi's arms from what turns out to be a burst [[stomach ulcer]]. The film then shows Emmi with Ali in the hospital, where a doctor tells her the illness is common among foreign workers because of the stress they face in everyday life; the doctor then adds that Ali will have surgery to remove the ulcer, but that he will probably be back in six months with another ulcer. Emmi declares that she will do everything in her power to prevent this and holds Ali's hand.
==Cast== * [[Brigitte Mira]] - Emmi Kurowski * [[El Hedi ben Salem]] - Ali * [[Barbara Valentin]] - Barbara * [[Irm Hermann]] - Krista * [[Rainer Werner Fassbinder]] - Eugen * Karl Scheydt - Albert Kurowski * [[Marquard Bohm]] - Gruber * [[Walter Sedlmayr]] - Angermayer * Doris Mattes - Mrs. Angermeyer (as Doris Mathes) * Lilo Pempeit - Mrs. Münchmeyer * Gusti Kreissl - Paula * [[Margit Symo]] - Hedwig * Elisabeth Bertram - Frieda * Helga Ballhaus - Yolanda * [[Elma Karlowa]] - Mrs. Kargus * Anita Bucher - Mrs. Ellis * Katharina Herberg - Woman in Bar
==Production== The film was shot in just under two weeks, and was planned as an exercise in film-making for Fassbinder, to fill in the time in his schedule between the work on two other films, ''[[Martha (1974 film)|Martha]]'' and ''[[Effi Briest (1974 film)|Effi Briest]]''.{{ref|1}}
Ali is played by [[El Hedi ben Salem]], who was Fassbinder's [[significant other|partner]] at the time. Fassbinder himself has a cameo appearance as Emmi's son in law. Emmi's daughter, Kristin, played by [[Irm Hermann]]), had herself a turbulent relationship with Fassbinder in real life, having been quoted as saying of Fassbinder, "He couldn't conceive of my refusing him, and he tried everything. He almost beat me to death on the streets of [[Bochum]] ....".<ref>{{harv|Baer|1986|p=65}}</ref> And Fassbinder himself grew up under some of the domestic effects of immigrant prejudice, given that his mother immigrated back to Germany from Poland after the Soviet Occupation and Fassbinder grew up in a turbulent and eventually divorcing household where immigrating relatives stayed with them.<ref>{{harv|Thomsen|2004|p=3}}</ref><ref>{{harv|Watson|1992|p=13}}</ref>
The original German title ''Angst essen Seele auf'' is deliberately grammatically incorrect, translating literally as "Fear eat soul up." The correct German form would be ''"Angst isst die Seele auf''" - which (without the definite article "die") became the title of a related 2002 short film also starring Mira. The title is one of the things Ali tells Emmi. As an immigrant, he speaks in what can be referred to as "[[Broken English|broken German]]" consistently throughout the film. The line of dialogue he utters is simply "Fear eat soul up." Since Ali's poor German grammar is translated literally in the film's English subtitles, the subtitles for Ali's dialogue are similarly riddled with grammatical errors.
''Ali'' is in part an homage to the films of [[Douglas Sirk]], in particular ''[[Imitation of Life (1959 film)|Imitation of Life]]'' (1959) and ''[[All That Heaven Allows]]'' (1955). The most overt homage is the scene in which Emmi's son kicks in the television (an important symbol in ''All That Heaven Allows'') after finding out that his mother has married a [[north African]].<ref name=Toteberg>{{cite web |url=http://www.criterion.com/current/posts/1068-ali-fear-eats-the-soul-all-that-fassbinder-allows |title=Ali: Fear Eats the Soul: All That Fassbinder Allows |first=Michael |last=Töteberg |date=1990 }} Posting of a published essay by Fassbinder's biographer and editor.</ref>
==Themes and symbolism== "Fear eats the soul", which is one of the things Ali says while talking with Emmi early in the movie, becomes almost literal later on, when it turns out that Ali has a stomach ulcer and is hospitalized. The characters are also often shown on screen in exaggerated ways; Characters are shown far away from the camera to emphasize how distant from society Emmi and Ali feel, while their apartment is shot in a claustrophobic manner, to symbolize the fear they feel in their relationship and everyday life.<ref name="Ebert Digital LLC">{{cite web|last1=Ebert|first1=Roger|title=Great Movie: Ali: Fear Eats the Soul|url=https://www.rogerebert.com/reviews/great-movie-ali-fear-eats-the-soul-1974|website=rogerebert.com|publisher=Ebert Digital LLC|accessdate=19 March 2018}}</ref>
==Release== ''Ali: Fear Eats the Soul'' was released in West Germany on March 5, 1974.<ref name="filmportal.de">{{cite web|url=https://www.filmportal.de/en/movie/angst-essen-seele-auf_ea43d4a6c4655006e03053d50b37753d|publisher=[[Filmportal.de]]|title=Angst essen Seele auf|accessdate=June 13, 2018|language=German}}</ref> The film has been released by [[the Criterion Collection]] as a region 1 DVD with English subtitles.<ref name=DVD>{{cite AV media |title=Ali: Fear Eats the Soul |publisher=The Criterion Collection |type=Blu-Ray (region 1) |date=September 30, 2014 |oclc=892562488 |isbn=9781604659030}} See {{cite AV media |title=Ali: Fear Eats the Soul |publisher=The Criterion Collection |type=DVD (region 1) |date=June 24, 2003 |oclc=779179093 |isbn=9781559409391}}</ref> The Blu-Ray contains the contents of both disks of the 2003 DVD release, which include interviews with actress Brigitte Mira and editor Thea Eymes. An [[BBC]] documentary based on famous German directors of the era, which compares Fassbinder, [[Werner Herzog]], and [[Wim Wenders]], is also included.<ref name=NYTretrospec>{{cite web|last1=Abramovich|first1=Alex|title=FILM/DVD'S; Further From Heaven|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2003/06/22/movies/film-dvd-s-further-from-heaven.html|website=nytimes.com|publisher=The New York Times Company|accessdate=23 March 2018}}</ref>
==Reception== ===Upon release=== The film gained critical acclaim upon its release, with the film's tone and Fassbinder's direction being signaled out as highlights. Writing for ''The [[Chicago Sun-Times]]'', [[Roger Ebert]] gave the film 4 out of 4 stars, saying: "[Fassbinder] nudges us to get outside the movie and look at it as absurd, as black humor, as [a] comment on these people so hopelessly trapped in their dreary surroundings and by their fates...Is [Fassbinder] sometimes being deliberately funny? I’m sure of it. His style and tone are so adamant that audiences sometimes just sit in silence, uncertain of the right response. With some films, that indicates the director’s loss of control over tone. With Fassbinder, it seems to be the response he wants."<ref>{{cite web|last1=Ebert|first1=Roger|title=Ali: Fear eats the soul review|url=https://www.rogerebert.com/reviews/ali-fear-eats-the-soul-1974|website=rogerebert.com|publisher=Ebert digital LLC|accessdate=20 March 2018}}</ref> Gene Moskowitz of ''[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]'' gave it a similarly positive review, calling the film "Not showy for exploitation, too observant and cool for robust hyoping".<ref>{{cite web|last1=Moskowitz|first1=Gene|title=Fear eats the soul out review|url=https://cinefiles.bampfa.berkeley.edu/cinefiles/DocDetail?docId=2983|website=cinefiles; the review came from Variety magazine|publisher=Variety Media, LLC|accessdate=20 March 2018}}</ref> Vincent Canby of ''[[The New York Times]]'' dissented somewhat, calling it a "Courageous attempt" and praising Mira and Salem's performances, while criticizing the "Posterlike Blandness" of the movie.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Canby|first1=Vincent|title=At the Film Festival: ‘Ali’|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1974/10/07/archives/at-the-film-festivalali-fassbinder-explore-racial-prejudice-the.html|website=nytimes.com|publisher=The New York Times Company|accessdate=27 March 2018}}</ref> Despite the acclaim his movie received, Fassbinder stated that he thought it was only the 8th best movie he made.<ref name="NYTretrospec"/>
===Modern reception=== The film has continued to receive positive reviews, with Mira and Salem's acting being praised as a highlight. On [[review aggregator]] website [[Rotten Tomatoes]], the film has an approval rating of 100%, based on 32 reviews, with an [[average rating]] of 9.5/10. The website's critical consensus reads, "Regarded as one of the high-water marks in German New Wave cinema of the 1970s, Ali: Fear Eats the Soul is at once an intense portrayal of a relationship and a tribute to one of Rainer Werner Fassbinder's film heroes, Douglas Sirk."<ref>{{cite web|title=ANGST ESSEN SEELE AUF (ALI: FEAR EATS THE SOUL)|url=https://www.rottentomatoes.com/m/fear_of_fear/|website=Rotten Tomatoes|publisher=Fandago|accessdate=26 March 2018}}</ref>
Writing for ''[[The New York Times]]'', Alex Abramovich calls ''Ali'' "The most thought-provoking, and beautiful, of [Fassbinder's] films"<ref name=NYTretrospec/> Richard Brody of ''[[The New Yorker]]'' praised the direction, saying "Fassbinder uses the camera with a precise, novelistic touch", and also praised Fassbinder's tributes to other films, saying "...[Fassbinder] didn't just make use of prior forms, he quoted them, and derived from them the ironies implicit in his melodramatic styles."<ref>{{cite web|last1=Brody|first1=Richard|title=DVD of the week: Ali: Fear eats the Soul|url=https://www.newyorker.com/culture/richard-brody/dvd-of-the-week-ali-fear-eats-the-soul|website=newyorker.com|publisher=Condé Nast|accessdate=26 March 2018}}</ref> Writing for ''[[The Guardian]]'', Peter Bradshaw calls Mira and Salem's performance "Superb", and "The most purely lovable characters I have ever seen on a movie screen".<ref>{{cite web|last1=Bradshaw|first1=Peter|title=Fear Eats the Soul review – love versus racism in Fassbinder's exquisite tale|url=https://www.theguardian.com/film/2017/mar/30/fear-eats-the-soul-review-love-versus-racism-in-fassbinders-exquisite-tale|website=thegaurdian.com|publisher=Guardian News and Media Limited|accessdate=27 March 2018}}</ref> Re-reviewing the movie for his ''[[Great Movies]]'' series of essays, [[Roger Ebert]] calls the film "Very powerful" and ends his review by saying, "“Ali: Fear Eats the Soul” might sound like improbable, contrived soap opera. It doesn’t play that way." <ref name="Ebert Digital LLC"/>
==Accolades== {| class="wikitable sortable" style="width: 99%;" |- ! scope="col"| Awards ! scope="col"| Date of ceremony ! scope="col"| Category ! scope="col"| Recipient(s) ! scope="col"| Result ! scope="col" class="unsortable"| {{Abbr|Ref(s)|Reference(s)}} |- | rowspan="1" | [[Cannes Film Festival]] | rowspan="1" | [[1974 Cannes Film Festival|May 9–24, 1974]] | [[FIPRESCI|International Federation of Film Critics best film (In competition)]] | [[Rainer Werner Fassbinder]] | {{won}} | rowspan="1" | <ref>{{cite web|title=FIPRESCI 1974 Cannes awards|url=http://www.fipresci.org/awards/1974|website=fipresci.org|accessdate=17 March 2018}}</ref> |- | rowspan="1" | [[Cannes Film Festival]] | rowspan="1" | [[1974 Cannes Film Festival|May 9–24, 1974]] | [[Prize of the Ecumenical Jury]] | ''Ali: Fear eats the soul'' | {{won}} | rowspan="1" | <ref>{{cite web|title=Tous les autres s’appellent Ali|url=http://cannes.juryoecumenique.org/palmares/article/tous-les-autres-s-appellent-ali|website=cannes.juryoecumenique.org|accessdate=17 March 2018|ref=JURY OECUMENIQUE au Festival de Cannes}}</ref> |}

{{See also|Folk music|Americana (music)}} {{Refimprove|date=June 2010}} {{USmusicgenres}}
The term '''American folk music''' encompasses numerous music genres, variously known as ''traditional music'', ''traditional [[folk music]]'', ''contemporary folk music'', or ''roots music''. Many traditional songs have been sung within the same family or folk group for generations, and sometimes trace back to such origins as Great Britain, Europe, or Africa.<ref name=afc>[https://www.loc.gov/folklife/guide/folkmusicandsong.html "Folk Music and Song", American Folklife Center, Library of Congress]</ref> Musician [[Mike Seeger]] once famously commented that the definition of American folk music is "...all the music that fits between the cracks."<ref>[http://catalog.youranswerplace.org/(riylqzaouv3t2j55dvrnwt21)/NewCopyListing.aspx?QS0=&QS1=2&QS2=Folk%20music%20United%20States&QS3=1&QS4=2&QS5=0&QS6=99&QS7=0&QS8=9999&QS9=0&QS10=99&QS11=263042&QS12=1&QS13=1&QS14=457430&QS15=9780399530333 catalog.youranswerplace.org]</ref>
Roots music is a broad category of music including [[bluegrass music|bluegrass]], [[gospel music|gospel]], [[old time music]], [[jug band]]s, [[Appalachian folk music|Appalachian folk]], [[blues]], [[Cajun music|Cajun]] and [[Native American music]]. The music is considered American either because it is native to the United States or because it developed there, out of foreign origins, to such a degree that it struck [[musicologist]]s as something distinctly new. It is considered "roots music" because it served as the basis of [[music of the United States|music later developed in the United States]], including [[rock and roll]], [[rhythm and blues]], and [[jazz]].
==Early American folk music== Most songs of the Colonial Fletch and Revolutionary period originated in England, Scotland and Ireland and were brought over by early settlers. "[[Barbara Allen (song)|Barbara Allen"]] remains a popular [[ballad|traditional ballad]] originating in England and Scotland, which immigrants introduced to the United States.<ref>Raph, Theodore. ''The American Song Treasury'', Dover Publications (1986)</ref> The [[murder ballad]] "[[Pretty Polly (ballad)|Pretty Polly]]" is an American version of an earlier British song, "The Gosport Tragedy".<ref name=pbs>[https://www.pbs.org/americanrootsmusic/pbs_arm_es_folkballad.html "Folk Songs and Ballads", American Roots Music, PBS]</ref>
===Spirituals=== {{Main|Spiritual (music)}} African American folk music in the area has roots in slavery and emancipation. "Sacred music, both a Capella and instrumentally accompanied, is at the heart of the tradition. Early spirituals framed Christian beliefs within native practices and were heavily influenced by the music and rhythms of Africa."<ref name = OklahomaFolk/> Spirituals are prominent, and often use a call and response pattern.<ref name = OklahomaFolk/> "Gospel developed after the Civil War (1861-65). It relied on biblical text for much of its direction, and the use of metaphors and imagery was common. Gospel is a "joyful noise," sometimes accompanied by instrumentation and almost always punctuated by hand clapping, toe tapping, and body movement."<ref name = OklahomaFolk/>
===Work songs===
====Sea shanties==== {{Main|Sea shanty}} Sea shanties functioned to lighten the burden of routine tasks and provide a rhythm that helped workers perform as a team.<ref name=afc/>
====Cowboy songs==== Cowboys songs are typically ballads that [[cowboy|cowboys]] sang in the West and Southwest. The familiar [[Streets of Laredo (song)|Streets of Laredo]]" (or "Cowboys Lament") derives from an Irish folk song of the late 18th century called "[[The Unfortunate Rake]]",<ref name=pbs/> which in turn appears to have descended from the even earlier "[[The Bard of Armagh]]". While "Streets of Laredo" uses the same melody as "The Unfortunate Rake", "[[St. James Infirmary Blues]]" adapts the story to a different tune. This illustrates how folk songs can change in the retelling and appear in a variety of versions.<ref name=afc/>
====Railroad songs==== The "Ballad of [[John Henry (folklore)]]" is about an African-American folk hero said to have worked as a "steel-driving man".<ref name=pbs/>
==Roots music== Many roots musicians do not consider themselves folk musicians. The main difference between the [[American folk music revival]] and American "roots music" is that roots music seems to cover a broader range, including blues and country.
Roots music developed its most expressive and varied forms in the first three decades of the 20th century. The [[Great Depression]] and the [[Dust Bowl]] were extremely important in disseminating these musical styles to the rest of the country, as [[Delta blues]] masters, itinerant [[honky tonk]] singers, [[Cajun]] musicians spread to cities like [[Chicago]], [[Los Angeles, California|Los Angeles]], and [[New York City|New York]]. The growth of the [[record industry|recording industry]] in the same period was also important; higher potential profits from music placed pressure on artists, songwriters, and label executives to replicate previous hit songs. This meant that musical fads, such as [[Hawaii]]an [[slack-key guitar]], never died out completely, since a broad range of rhythms, instruments, and vocal stylings were incorporated into disparate popular genres.
By the 1950s, forms of roots music had led to pop-oriented forms. Folk musicians like the [[Kingston Trio]], blues-derived [[rock and roll]] and [[rockabilly]], pop-gospel, [[doo wop]] and [[R&B]] (later secularized further as [[soul music]]) and the [[Nashville sound]] in country music all modernized and expanded the musical palette of the country.
The roots approach to music emphasizes the diversity of American musical traditions, the genealogy of creative lineages and communities, and the innovative contributions of musicians working in these traditions today. In recent years roots music has been the focus of popular media programs such as [[Garrison Keillor]]'s public radio program, ''[[A Prairie Home Companion]]'' and the feature film by the same name.
==Regional forms== American traditional music is also called roots music. Roots music is a broad category of music including [[bluegrass music|bluegrass]], [[country music]], [[gospel music|gospel]], [[old time music]], [[jug band]]s, [[Appalachian folk music|Appalachian folk]], [[blues]], [[Cajun music|Cajun]] and [[Native American music]]. The music is considered American either because it is native to the United States or because it developed there, out of foreign origins, to such a degree that it struck [[musicologist]]s as something distinctly new. It is considered "roots music" because it served as the basis of music later developed in the United States, including [[rock and roll]], contemporary folk music, [[rhythm and blues]], and [[jazz]].
===Appalachian music=== {{See also|Music of East Tennessee}} [[Appalachian music]] is the traditional music of the region of [[Appalachia]] in the Eastern United States. It derives from various European and African influences—including English [[ballad]]s, Irish and Scottish traditional music (especially [[fiddle]] music), hymns, and African-American blues. First recorded in the 1920s, Appalachian musicians were a key influence on the early development of [[Old-time music]], [[country music]], and [[bluegrass music|bluegrass]], and were an important part of the [[American folk music revival]].
Instruments typically used to perform Appalachian music include the [[banjo]], [[American fiddle]], [[Appalachian dulcimer|fretted dulcimer]], and [[guitar]].<ref name=olson>Ted Olson, "Music — Introduction". ''Encyclopedia of Appalachia'' (Knoxville, Tenn.: University of Tennessee Press, 2006), pp. 1109—1120.</ref>
Early recorded Appalachian musicians include [[Fiddlin' John Carson]], [[Henry Whitter]], [[Bascom Lamar Lunsford]], the [[Carter Family]], [[Clarence Ashley]], [[Frank Proffitt]], and [[Dock Boggs]], all of whom were initially recorded in the 1920s and 1930s. Several Appalachian musicians obtained renown during the folk revival of the 1950s and 1960s, including [[Jean Ritchie]], [[Roscoe Holcomb]], [[Ola Belle Reed]], [[Lily May Ledford]], and [[Doc Watson]].
The Carter Family was a traditional American folk music group that recorded between 1927 and 1956. Their music had a profound impact on [[bluegrass music|bluegrass]], [[country music|country]], [[Southern Gospel]], [[popular music|pop]] and [[rock music]]ians. They were the first vocal group to become country music stars; a beginning of the divergence of country music from traditional folk music. Their recordings of such songs as "[[Wabash Cannonball]]" (1932), "[[Can the Circle Be Unbroken (By and By)|Will the Circle Be Unbroken]]" (1935), "[[Wildwood Flower]]" (1928), and "[[Keep on the Sunny Side]]" (1928) made them country standards.<ref>{{cite book |title=The Definitive Illustrated Encyclopedia of Rock |last=Heatley |first=Michael |coauthors= |year=2007 |publisher=Star Fire |location=London, United Kingdom |isbn=978-1-84451-996-5 }}</ref>
Country and bluegrass artists such as [[Loretta Lynn]], [[Roy Acuff]], [[Dolly Parton]], [[Earl Scruggs]], [[Chet Atkins]], and [[Don Reno]] were heavily influenced by traditional Appalachian music.<ref name=olson /> Artists such as [[Bob Dylan]], [[Jerry Garcia]], and [[Bruce Springsteen]] have performed Appalachian songs or rewritten versions of Appalachian songs.
===Cajun music=== [[Cajun music]], an emblematic [[music of Louisiana]], is rooted in the [[ballads]] of the French-speaking [[Acadian]]s of [[Canada]]. Cajun music is often mentioned in tandem with the [[Louisiana Creole people|Creole]]-based, [[Cajun]]-influenced [[zydeco]] form, both of [[Acadiana]] origin. These [[French Louisiana#Modern French Louisiana|French Louisiana]] sounds have influenced [[American popular music]] for many decades, especially country music, and have influenced pop culture through mass media, such as television commercials.
===Oklahoma and southern US plains=== [[File:Woody Guthrie NYWTS.jpg|thumb|left|230px|Singer-songwriter [[Woody Guthrie]] emerged from the dust bowl of Oklahoma and the [[Great Depression in the United States|Great Depression]] in the mid-20th Century, with lyrics that embraced his views on ecology, poverty, and [[Trade union|unionization in the USA.]], paired with melody reflecting the many genres of American folk music.]] Before recorded history American Indians in this area used songs and instrumentation; music and dance remain the core of ceremonial and social activities.<ref name = OklahomaFolk/> "Stomp dance" remains at its core, a "call and response" form; instrumentation is provided by rattles or shackles worn on the legs of women.<ref name = OklahomaFolk>[http://digital.library.okstate.edu/encyclopedia/entries/F/FO010.html Encyclopedia of Oklahoma History and Culture - Folk Music]</ref> "Other southeastern nations have their own complexes of sacred and social songs, including those for animal dances and friendship dances, and songs that accompany stickball games.
Central to the music of the southern Plains Indians is the drum, which has been called the heartbeat of Plains Indian music. Most of that genre traces back to the hunting and warfare that was a strong part of plains culture.<ref name = OklahomaFolk/> During the reservation period, they frequently used music to relieve boredom and despair. Neighbors gathered, exchanged and created songs and dances. This is a part of the roots of the modern intertribal [[powwow]]. Another common instrument is the courting flute.<ref name = OklahomaFolk/>
[[Shape-note]] or [[sacred harp]] singing developed in the early nineteenth century as a way for itinerant singing instructors to teach church songs in rural communities. They taught using song books that represented musical notation of tones by geometric shapes that associated a shape with a pitch. Sacred harp singing became popular in many Oklahoma rural communities, regardless of ethnicity.<ref name=OklahomaFolk/>
Later, the blues tradition developed, with roots in and parallels to sacred music.<ref name = OklahomaFolk/> By the early 20th century, jazz developed, born from a "blend of ragtime, gospel, and blues"<ref name = OklahomaFolk/> "Anglo-Scots-Irish music traditions gained a place in Oklahoma after the Land Run of 1889. Because of its size and portability, the fiddle was the core of early Oklahoma Anglo music, but other instruments such as the guitar, mandolin, banjo, and steel guitar were added later. Various Oklahoma music traditions trace their roots to the British Isles, including cowboy ballads, western swing, and contemporary country and western."<ref name = OklahomaFolk/> "Mexican immigrants began to reach Oklahoma in the 1870s, bringing beautiful canciones and corridos love songs, waltzes, and ballads along with them. Like American Indian communities, each rite of passage in Hispanic communities is accompanied by traditional music.
The acoustic guitar, string bass, and violin provide the basic instrumentation for Mexican music, with maracas, flute, horns, or sometimes accordion filling out the sound."<ref name = OklahomaFolk/> Other Europeans (such as Bohemians and Germans) settled in the late nineteenth century. Their social activities centered on community halls, "where local musicians played polkas and waltzes on the accordion, piano, and brass instruments."<ref name = OklahomaFolk/>
Later Asians contributed to the musical mix. "Ancient music and dance traditions from the temples and courts of China, India, and Indonesia are preserved in Asian communities throughout the state, and popular song genres are continually layered on to these classical music forms"<ref name = OklahomaFolk/>
===The American Southwest and South Texas=== [[Tejano music|Tejano]] and [[New Mexico music]], heard throughout the [[American Southwest]] and [[South Texas]], is rooted in the musics of the [[Indigenous peoples of the Americas|Native American]] and [[Hispanic and Latino Americans|Hispanic/Latino]] communities of the regions. Tejano music is also heavily influenced by [[Regional Mexican music|Regional Mexican]] and Country music, while New Mexico music is much more influenced by [[Hispanos of New Mexico|Hispano]] folk and [[Western music (North America)|Western music]]. Both styles have influenced one another over the years, and incorporated American popular music styles.
==Other American folk music== Genres here range as widely as the definition of folk music itself; working definitions are based on the style and themes of the music regardless of its source. Many are a part of the [[American Folk Music Revival]], including works by [[Pete Seeger]], [[Woody Guthrie]], [[The Weavers]],{{sfn|Gilliland|1969|loc=show 18}} [[Burl Ives]], and others. A more commercially oriented pop music version of folk emerged in the 1960s, including performers such as [[The Kingston Trio]],{{sfn|Gilliland|1969|loc=show 18}} [[The Limeliters]], [[The Brothers Four]], [[Peter, Paul and Mary]], [[Joan Baez]],{{sfn|Gilliland|1969|loc=show 19}} [[The Highwaymen (folk band)|The Highwaymen]], [[Judy Collins]], [[The New Christy Minstrels]], and [[Gordon Lightfoot]], as well as counterculture and folk rock performers including [[Bob Dylan]],{{sfn|Gilliland|1969|loc=shows 31-32}} [[The Byrds]], [[Arlo Guthrie]], and [[Buffy Sainte-Marie]].{{sfn|Gilliland|1969|loc=show 33}} Folk composer and musician [[Robert Schmertz (artist)|Robert Schmertz]] composed and wrote [[List of songs by Robert Schmertz|pieces]] related to historical events in Western Pennsylvania.<ref name="Journal_obituary">{{cite journal|url=https://journals.psu.edu/wph/article/viewFile/3386/3217|title=Historical Society Notes and Documents: Robert Watson Schmertz|last=Swetnam|first=George|volume=54|number=4|journal=The Western Pennsylvania Historical Magazine|year=October 1975|pages=537–538}} {{open access}}</ref><ref name="Covers,_Bio">{{cite news|url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/3528108/composer_architect_entertains_avon_club/|title=Composer, Architect Entertains Avon Club|newspaper=News Record|date=October 27–28, 1973|page=11}}</ref>
==Books== In 2004, [[NPR]] published the book titled ''The NPR Curious Listener's Guide to American Folk Music'',<ref name="foreword">{{cite web | title=Amazon | work=The NPR Curious Listener's Guide to American Folk Music, by Kip Lornell (Author), Linda Ronstadt (Foreword) | url=https://www.amazon.com/Curious-Listeners-Guide-American-Music/dp/0399530339 | accessdate=May 17, 2007}}</ref> [[Linda Ronstadt]] wrote the [[foreword]]. * [http://www.press.uillinois.edu/books/catalog/48nks6er9780252033339.html The Never-Ending Revival: Rounder Records and the Folk Alliance by Michael F. Scully (University of Illinois Press, 2008)]
In 2007, [[James P. Leary]] published ''Polkabilly: How the Goose Island Ramblers Redefined American Folk Music'', which proposes a redefinition of traditional American folk music and identifies a new genre of music from the [[Upper Midwest]] known as ''Polkabilly'', which blends ethnic music, old-time country music, and polka.<ref>[https://www.jstor.org/stable/10.5406/jamerfolk.123.489.0363 "Journal of American Folklore: Review"], Retrieved 27 April 2013.</ref> The book was awarded the [[American Folklore Society]]’s Chicago Folklore Prize for the best book in the field of folklore scholarship.<ref>[http://www.afsnet.org/?page=Chicago "Chicago Folklore Prize"], Retrieved 27 April 2013.</ref>
==Artists and musicians==
Notable American folk/roots musicians include:
{{Div col|colwidth=18em}} * [[Fiddlin' John Carson]] (1868–1949) * [[Joe Hill]] (1879-1915) * [[Washington Phillips]] (1880-1954) * [[Lead Belly]] (1888-1949) * [[Jelly Roll Morton]] (1890-1941) * [[Blind Lemon Jefferson]] (1892-1929) * [[Bessie Smith]] (1894-1937) * [[Elizabeth Cotten]] (1895-1987) * [[Jimmie Rodgers (country singer)|Jimmie Rodgers]] "The Singing Brakeman" (1897-1933) * [[Paul Robeson]] (1898-1976) * [[Son House]] (1902-1988) * [[Roy Acuff]] (1903-1992) * Johnny Richardson (1908–2014; children's folk music)<ref>http://northcountrynow.com/obituaries/john-johnny-richardson-105-madrid</ref> * [[Burl Ives]] (1909-1995) * [[Earl Robinson]] (1910-1991) * [[Robert Johnson (musician)|Robert Johnson]] (1911-1938) * [[Mahalia Jackson]] (1911-1972) * [[Sonny Terry]] (1911-1986) * [[Bill Monroe]] (1911-1996) * [[Woody Guthrie]] (1912-1967) * [[Roscoe Holcomb]] (1912-1981) * [[Muddy Waters]] (1913-1983) * [[Lester Flatt]] (1914-1979) and [[Earl Scruggs]] (1924-2012) * [[Brownie McGhee]] (1915-1996) * [[Ola Belle Reed]] (1916-2002) * [[Lily May Ledford]] (1917-1984) * [[John Lee Hooker]] (1917-2001) * [[Merle Travis]] (1917-1983) * [[Cisco Houston]] (1918-1961) * [[Ed McCurdy]] (1919-2000) * [[Pete Seeger]] (1919-2014) * [[Doc Watson]] (1923-2012) * [[Jean Ritchie]] (1922-2015) * [[Hank Williams]] (1923-1953) * [[Fred Gerlach]] (1925-2009) * [[B.B. King]] (1925-2015) * [[Barbara Dane]] (1927-) * [[Ralph Stanley]] (1927-2016) * [[Logan English]] (1928-1983) * [[Ramblin' Jack Elliott]] (1931-) * [[Paul Clayton (folksinger)|Paul Clayton]] (1931-1967) * [[Bob Gibson]] (1931-1996) * [[Johnny Cash]] (1932-2003) * [[Ian & Sylvia|Ian Tyson (1933-) and Sylvia Fricker (1940-)]] * [[Mike Seeger]] (1933-2009) * [[Willie Nelson]] (1933-) * [[Liam Clancy]] (1935-2009) * [[Hazel Dickens]] (1935-2011) * [[Dave Van Ronk]] (1936-2002) * [[Carolyn Hester]] (1937-) * [[Trini Lopez]] (1937-) * [[Norman Blake (American musician)|Norman Blake]] (1938-) * [[Gordon Lightfoot]] (1938-) * [[Hoyt Axton]] (1938-1999) * [[Judy Collins]] (1939-) * [[Mark Spoelstra]] (1940-2007) * [[Joan Baez]] (1941-) * [[Bob Dylan]] (1941-) * [[Buffy Sainte-Marie]] (1941-) * [[Roger McGuinn]] (1942-) * [[Joni Mitchell]] (1943-) * [[John Denver]] (1943-1997) * [[Townes Van Zandt]] (1944-1997) * [[Linda Ronstadt]] (1946-) * [[Arlo Guthrie]] (1947-) * [[Greg Brown (folk musician)|Greg Brown]] (1949-) * [[Bruce Springsteen]] (1949-) * [[Keb' Mo']] (1951-) * [[Ricky Skaggs]] (1954-) * [[Chris Castle]] (1976-) * [[Pokey LaFarge]] (1983-) * [[Chris Thile]] (1981-) * [[Sarah Jarosz]] (1991-) * [[Aoife O'Donovan]] (1982) * [[Maggie Simpson (musician)|Maggie Simpson]] * [[Odetta]] (1930-2008) * [[Rhiannon Giddens]] (1977-) * [[Jack Warshaw]] (1942-) {{div col end}}
Groups:
{{Div col|colwidth=18em}} * [[The Big 3 (folk group)|The Big 3]] * [[The Brothers Four]] * [[Bud & Travis]] * [[The Byrds]] * [[Carter Family]] * [[The Chad Mitchell Trio]] * [[Foggy Mountain Boys]] * [[The Highwaymen (folk band)|The Highwaymen]] * [[The Irish Rovers]] * [[The Journeymen]] * [[Kenny Rogers and The First Edition]] * [[The Kingston Trio]] * [[The Limeliters]] * [[The Mamas & the Papas]] * [[The New Christy Minstrels]] * [[New Lost City Ramblers]] * [[Peter, Paul & Mary]] * [[Pozo-Seco Singers]] * [[The Sandpipers]] * [[The Serendipity Singers]] * [[The Simon Sisters]] * [[Smothers Brothers]] * [[Spanky and Our Gang]] * [[Stone Poneys]] * [[The Tarriers]] * [[Virginia Minstrels]] * [[The Weavers]] * [[Punch Brothers]] * [[Nickel Creek]] * [[Crooked Still]] {{div col end}}
<gallery> File:Fiddlin'JohnCarson.jpg|Fiddlin' John Carson File:MortonBricktopRowCropMortonFace.jpg|Jelly Roll Morton File:Leadbelly with Accordeon.jpg|Lead Belly File:Carter Family 1927.jpg|The Carter Family File:Woody Guthrie 2.jpg|Woody Guthrie File:Burl Ives (Cat on a Hot Tin Roof) 1958.jpg|Burl Ives File:Pete Seeger2 - 6-16-07 Photo by Anthony Pepitone.jpg|Pete Seeger File:Kingston_Trio.jpg|The Kingston Trio File:Joan Baez Hamburg 1973 2811730005.jpg|Joan Baez File:Peter paul and mary publicity photo.JPG|Peter, Paul and Mary </gallery>
==Film and TV== {{listen |filename=Yellow Rose Of Texas.ogg |title="Yellow Rose Of Texas" (1858) |description="[[The Yellow Rose of Texas (song)|The Yellow Rose of Texas]]" performed by the [[United States Coast Guard Band]] |filetype=[[Ogg]] |filename2=Oh Susanna.ogg |title2="Oh! Susanna" (1848) |description2=[[Stephen Foster]]'s "[[Oh! Susanna]]" performed by the [[United States Navy Band|United States Navy Concert Band]] |filetype2=[[Ogg]] |pos=right}}
''[[Hootenanny (U.S. TV series)|Hootenanny]]'', a weekly musical variety show broadcast on the ABC network in the U.S. in 1963-1964, primarily featured folk musicians.
The soundtrack of the 2000 [[film]] ''[[O Brother, Where Art Thou?]]'' is exclusively roots music, performed by [[Alison Krauss]], [[The Fairfield Four]], [[Emmylou Harris]], [[Norman Blake (American musician)|Norman Blake]] and others.
In 2001, [[Public Broadcasting Service|PBS]] broadcast a 4-part [[documentary film|documentary]] series, ''American Roots Music,'' that explored the historical roots of American roots music through footage and performances by the creators of the movement.
The 2003 film ''[[A Mighty Wind]]'' is a tribute to (and parody of) the folk-pop musicians of the early 1960s.
A six-hour public television series, ''The Music of America: History Through Musical Traditions,'' appeared in 2010.
==See also== *[[American folk music revival]] *''[[Anthology of American Folk Music]]'' *[[List of North American folk music traditions]] *[[Protest songs in the United States]]

{{infobox book | <!-- See Wikipedia:WikiProject_Novels or Wikipedia:WikiProject_Books --> | name = Ang mga Anak Dalita | title_orig = | translator = | image = File:Ang mga anak dalita bookcover 1911.jpg | image_size= 250px | caption = Original cover | author = [[Patricio Mariano]] | cover_artist = | country = [[Philippines]] | language = [[Tagalog language|Tagalog]] | genre = Novel | publisher = Limbagan at Aklatan Ni I.R. Morales | release_date = 1911 | media_type = Print | pages = 73 | dewey= | congress= | preceded_by = [[Juan Masili: Ang Pinuno ng Tulisan]] | followed_by = [[Ang Tala sa Panghulo]] }}
'''''Ang mga Anak Dalita''''' ("[The] Children of the Poor"<ref name=Itunes>{{cite web|url=https://itunes.apple.com/us/book/ang-mga-anak-dalita-children/id397317165?mt=11|title=Ang mga Anak Dalita (Children of the Poor) by Patricio Mariano|publisher=Apple Inc|accessdate=June 24, 2011}}</ref>) is a 1911 [[Tagalog language|Tagalog]]-language novel written by [[Filipino people|Filipino]] novelist [[Patricio Mariano]]. The 73-page novel was published in [[Manila]] by Limbagan at Aklatan Ni I.R. Morales (Printing Press And Library of I.R. Morales) during the [[History of the Philippines (1898–1946)|American era]] in [[Philippine history]] (1898–1946). ''Ang mga Anak Dalita'' is a [[political novel]] that deals also with Filipino ideology, the socio-economic situation, the industrial upheaval, and the struggle of the oppressed Filipino working class in Manila during Mariano’s time.<ref name=Itunes/><ref name=Filipiniana/>
==Description== [[File:Ang mga Anak Dalita bookcover2.jpg|right|Contemporary cover|200px]] Mariano wrote ''Ang mga Anak Dalita'' in [[poetic form]]. The theme of the novel is about how the poor in the Philippines become poorer by being exploited by capitalists. According to literary critic [[Soledad Reyes]], there was a scene in the novel wherein Ata, the main female protagonist, narrates a story about how the Philippines (represented by the name "Mutya", meaning "pearl", "precious stone", or "charmstone"<ref name=Bansa1>{{cite web|url=http://www.bansa.org/dictionaries/tgl/?dict_lang=tgl&type=search&data=mutya|title=Mutya, pearl, precious stone, charmstone|publisher=Bansa|accessdate=July 4, 2011}}</ref>) became the victim of Spain (represented by the name "Dulong", a type of small fish<ref name=Bansa2>{{cite web|url=http://www.bansa.org/dictionaries/tgl/?dict_lang=tgl&type=search&data=dulong|title=Dulong|publisher=Bansa|accessdate=July 4, 2011}}</ref> known as the ''Gobiopterus lacustris'' (Lacustrine goby), which belongs to the [[Gobiidae]] family),<ref name=Mongabay>{{cite web|url=http://fish.mongabay.com/data/Philippines.htm|title=Gobiidae, Gobiopterus lacustris, Lacustrine goby, Dulong, List of Freshwater Fishes for Philippines|first=Rhett|last=Buttler|publisher=Mongabay.com|accessdate=July 4, 2011}}</ref> and the United States (represented by the name "Limatik", meaning "[[leech]]"<ref name=Gabby>{{cite web|url=http://www.gabbydictionary.com/home.asp|title=Leech, limatik|publisher=Gabby's Dictionary|accessdate=July 4, 2011| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110711062445/http://www.gabbydictionary.com/home.asp| archivedate= July 11, 2011 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref>).<ref name=Filipiniana/> Based on Philippine history, the Philippines was colonized by Spain from 1521 to 1898, and then by the United States from 1898 to 1946.<ref name=Filipiniana/>
==Plot== The characters of the novel include Ata, Teta, Pedro, and a factory owner. Ata is a poor woman. Teta is Ata’s daughter. Pedro is Ata’s lover. The factory owner in the novel is the “[[avarice|avaricious]]” and “[[lust]]ful" boss of Ata. The factory owner tried to rape Ata, but she was able to escape. During a conflict with the laborers, Ata’s daughter Teta saves the factory owner from being killed by the factory workers. In the end, Teta turns out to be the daughter of the factory owner. The theme of the novel is similar to Mariano’s other novel ''[[Ang Tala sa Panghulo]]'' ("The Bright Star at Panghulo").<ref name=Filipiniana>{{cite web|url=http://www.filipiniana.net/publication/ang-mga-anak-dalita/12791881584511 |title=Ang mga Anak Dalita by Mariano, Patricio |publisher=Filipiniana |accessdate=June 24, 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120128225829/http://www.filipiniana.net/publication/ang-mga-anak-dalita/12791881584511 |archivedate=January 28, 2012 }}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== *[http://www.gutenberg.org/ebooks/18888 Ang mga Anak Dalita by Patricio Mariano] at Project Gutenberg
{{DEFAULTSORT:Ang Mga Anak Dalita}} [[Category:Philippine novels]] [[Category:1911 novels]] [[Category:Tagalog-language novels]] [[Category:Political novels]] [[Category:Novels set in the Philippines]]

page.title: Ariel Center for the Performing Arts

revision.text:
The '''Ariel Performing Arts Center''' ({{lang-he|המשכן לאומנויות הבמה אריאל}}, ''HaMishkan LeOmanuyot HaBama Ariel'') is an [[Israel]]i [[performing arts]] complex, established in 2010 in [[Ariel (city)|Ariel]] on the [[West Bank]]. It opened on November 8, 2010 with an acclaimed performance of [[Piaf (play)|Piaf]] by the [[Beersheba Theater]] company.<ref>Chaim Levinson, "Major theaters raise curtain across Green Line", ''[[Haaretz]]'', 25 August 2010 [http://www.haaretz.com/print-edition/news/major-theaters-raise-curtain-across-green-line-1.310040 full text]</ref>
The opening was mired by an intended boycott by sixty actors, writers, and directors, including [[Joshua Sobol]], who refuse to perform in settlements because it would "strengthen the settlement enterprise". Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu and other right-wing commentators characterized this as a "boycott... against Israel's citizens".<ref>Dan Williams, "Israeli actors boycott theatres in settlements", ''Reuters AlertNet'' 29 August 2010 [http://www.alertnet.org/thenews/newsdesk/LDE67S04H.htm]</ref><ref>Donald Macintyre, "Israeli actors refuse to take the stage in settlement theatre", ''[[The Independent]]'', 30 August 2010 [https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/middle-east/israeli-actors-refuse-to-take-the-stage-in-settlement-theatre-2065489.html]</ref> The boycott is being supported by other Israeli artists such as [[Amos Oz]], [[David Grossman]], and [[Dani Caravan]],;<ref>Chaim Levinson, "U.S. actors back Israeli boycott of West Bank theater", ''[[Haaretz]]'', 6 September 2010 [http://www.haaretz.com/print-edition/news/u-s-actors-back-israeli-boycott-of-west-bank-theater-1.312393 full text]</ref> 150 U.S. actors have supported them in an open letter.<ref>"Making history: support for Israeli artists who say NO to normalizing settlements", [[Jewish Voice for Peace]] [http://www.jewishvoiceforpeace.org/campaigns/making-history-support-israeli-artists-who-say-no-normalizing-settlements-4 full text]</ref> though none of them have actually been invited to perform.
==References== <references/>
[[Category:Arts organizations established in 2010]] [[Category:Israeli culture]] [[Category:Performing arts centres]]
