Chinese musical instruments were traditionally grouped into 8 categories known as ''bayin'' ([[wikt:八音|八音]]).<ref name="harvard">{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=02rFSecPhEsC&pg=PA260&f=false#v=onepage&q&f=false |title=The Harvard Dictionary of Music |editor= Don Michael Randel |pages=260–262 |publisher=Harvard University Press |edition=4th |year= 2003 |isbn=978-0674011632 }}</ref> The eight categories are: [[silk]], [[bamboo]], [[wood]], [[Rock (geology)|stone]], [[metal]], [[clay]], [[gourd]] and [[skin]]. There are other instruments which may not fit these groups. This is one of the first musical groups ever devised.
==Silk ([[wikt:絲|絲]])== Silk instruments are mostly [[stringed instruments]] (including those that are plucked, bowed, and struck). Since ancient times the Chinese have used twisted silk for strings, though today metal or nylon are more frequently used. Instruments in the silk category include:
===Plucked=== *[[Guqin|Qin]] – Chinese historical zither, early zither in Chinese.An ancient classical Chinese musical instrument similar to Guqin. *[[Guqin]] ({{zh|c=[[wikt:古琴|古琴]]|p=gǔqín}}) – 7-stringed zithers *[[Se (instrument)|Se]] ({{zh|c=[[wikt:瑟|瑟]]|p=sè}}) – 25-stringed zither with movable bridges (ancient sources say 13, 25 or 50 strings) *[[Guzheng|Zheng]] ([[wikt:Chinese|Chinese]]) – Similar to Guzheng *[[Guzheng]] ([[wikt:古箏|古箏]]) – 16–26 stringed zither with movable bridges *[[Konghou]] ([[wikt:箜篌|箜篌]]) – harp *[[Pipa]] ([[wikt:琵琶|琵琶]]) – pear-shaped fretted lute with 4 or 5 strings *[[Sanxian]] ([[wikt:三弦|三弦]]) – plucked lute with body covered with snakeskin and long fretless neck *[[Ruan]] ({{zh|c=[[wikt:阮|阮]]|p=ruǎn}}) – moon-shaped lute in five sizes: ''gaoyin-'', ''xiao-'', ''zhong-'', ''da-'', and ''diyin-''; sometimes called ''ruanqin'' (阮琴) *[[Liuqin]] ([[wikt:柳琴|柳琴]]) – small plucked, fretted lute with a pear-shaped body and four strings *[[Yueqin]] ([[wikt:月琴|月琴]]) – plucked lute with a wooden body, a short fretted neck, and four strings tuned in pairs *[[Qinqin]] ([[wikt:秦琴|秦琴]]) – plucked lute with a wooden body and fretted neck; also called ''meihuaqin'' (梅花琴, literally "plum blossom instrument", from its flower-shaped body) *[[Duxianqin]] ({{zh|t=[[wikt:獨弦琴|獨弦琴]]|s=[[wikt:独弦琴|独弦琴]]}}) – the instrument of the Jing People (Vietnamese people in China) plucked zither with only one string a monochord zither tuned to C3. *[[Wenqin]] (文琴) – a combination of the erhu , konghou , sanxian and guzheng with 50 or more strings made of silk.'' *[[Wenzhenqin]] (文枕琴) – a zither with 25 or more strings either plucked or bowed *[[Huobosi]] ([[wikt:火不思|火不思]]) – a plucked long-necked lute of Turkic origin *[[Tembor]] ([[wikt:弹拨尔|弹拨尔]]) – a fretted plucked long-necked lute with five strings in three courses, used in Uyghur traditional music of Xinjiang *[[Dutar]] ([[wikt:都塔尔|都塔尔]]) – a fretted plucked long-necked lute with two strings, used in Uyghur traditional music of Xinjiang *[[Rawap]] ([[wikt:热瓦普|热瓦普]] or [[wikt:热瓦甫|热瓦甫]]) – a fretless plucked long-necked lute used in Uyghur traditional music of Xinjiang
===Bowed=== [[Image:ConcertGroupPano.jpg|thumb|right|350px|Re-enactment of an ancient traditional music performance]] [[File:Paintings on north wall of Xu Xianxiu Tomb.jpg|thumb|350px|A mural from the tomb of Xu Xianxiu in [[Taiyuan]], [[Shanxi]] province, dated 571 AD during the [[Northern Qi Dynasty]], showing male court musicians playing stringed instruments, either the ''[[liuqin]]'' or ''[[pipa]]'', and a woman playing a ''[[konghou]]'' (harp)]] *[[Huqin]] ([[wikt:胡琴|胡琴]]) – family of vertical fiddles *[[Erhu]] ([[wikt:二胡|二胡]]) – two-stringed fiddle *[[Zhonghu]] ([[wikt:中胡|中胡]]) – two-stringed fiddle, lower pitch than an erhu *[[Gaohu]] ([[wikt:高胡|高胡]]) – two-stringed fiddle, higher pitch than erhu; also called ''yuehu'' ([[wikt:粤|粤]][[wikt:胡|胡]]) *[[Banhu]] ([[wikt:板胡|板胡]]) – two-stringed fiddle with a coconut resonator and wooden face, used primarily in northern China *[[Jinghu (instrument)|Jinghu]] ([[wikt:京胡|京胡]]) – two-stringed fiddle, very high pitched, used mainly for Beijing opera *[[Jing erhu]] (京二胡) – ''erhu'' used in Beijing opera *[[Erxian]] ([[wikt:二弦|二弦]]) – two-stringed fiddle, used in Cantonese, Chaozhou, and nanguan music *[[Tiqin]] ([[wikt:提琴|提琴]]) – two-stringed fiddle, used in ''kunqu'', Chaozhou, Cantonese, Fujian, and Taiwanese music *[[Yehu]] ([[wikt:椰胡|椰胡]]) – two-stringed fiddle with coconut body, used primarily in Cantonese and Chaozhou music *[[Daguangxian]] ([[wikt:大广弦|大广弦]]) – two-stringed fiddle used in Taiwan and Fujian, primarily by Min Nan and Hakka people; also called ''datongxian'' ([[wikt:大筒弦|大筒弦]]), ''guangxian'' (广弦), and ''daguanxian'' (大管弦) *[[Datong (instrument)|Datong]] ([[wikt:大筒|大筒]]) – two-stringed fiddle used in the traditional music of Hunan *[[Kezaixian]] (壳仔弦) – two-stringed fiddle with coconut body, used in [[Taiwan opera]] *[[Liujiaoxian]] (六角弦) – two-stringed fiddle with hexagonal body, similar to the ''jing erhu''; used primarily in Taiwan *[[Tiexianzai]] (鐵弦仔) – a two-stringed fiddle with metal amplifying horn at the end of its neck, used in Taiwan; also called ''guchuixian'' (鼓吹弦) *[[Hexian]] (和弦) – large fiddle used primarily among the Hakka of Taiwan *[[Huluqin]] (葫芦琴) – two-stringed fiddle with gourd body used by the [[Naxi people|Naxi]] of [[Yunnan]] *[[Huluhu]] ({{zh|t=葫盧胡|s=葫芦胡}}) – two-stringed fiddle with gourd body used by the Zhuang of Guangxi *[[Maguhu]] ({{zh|t=馬骨胡|s=马骨胡|p=mǎgǔhú}}) – two-stringed fiddle with horse bone body used by the Zhuang and Buyei peoples of southern China *[[Tuhu]] (土胡) – two-stringed fiddle used by the Zhuang people of Guangxi *[[Jiaohu]] (角胡) – two-stringed fiddle used by the [[Gelao people|Gelao]] people of Guangxi, as well as the Miao and Dong *[[Sihu (instrument)|Sihu]] ([[wikt:四胡|四胡]]) – four-stringed fiddle with strings tuned in pairs *[[Sanhu]] (三胡) – 3-stringed ''erhu'' with an additional bass string; developed in the 1970s [http://www.soomal.com/gb/002/001/00000012.htm] *[[Zhuihu]] ({{zh|t=墜胡|s=坠胡}}) – two-stringed fiddle with fingerboard *[[Zhuiqin]] (traditional: 墜琴; simplified: 坠琴) – two-stringed fiddle with fingerboard *[[Leiqin]] ([[wikt:雷琴|雷琴]]) – two-stringed fiddle with fingerboard *[[Dihu]] ([[wikt:低胡|低胡]]) – low pitched two-stringed fiddles in the ''erhu'' family, in three sizes: *Xiaodihu (小低胡) – small ''dihu'', tuned one octave below the ''erhu'' *Zhongdihu (中低胡) – medium ''dihu'', tuned one octave below the ''zhonghu'' *Dadihu (大低胡) – large ''dihu'', tuned two octaves below the erhu *[[Dahu (instrument)|Dahu]] (大胡) – another name for the ''xiaodihu'' *[[Cizhonghu]] – another name for the ''xiaodihu'' *[[Gehu]] ([[wikt:革胡|革胡]]) – four-stringed bass instrument, tuned and played like cello *[[Diyingehu]] (低音革胡) – four stringed contrabass instrument, tuned and played like double bass *[[Laruan]] ([[wikt:拉阮|拉阮]]) – four-stringed bowed instrument modeled on the cello *[[Paqin]] (琶琴) – modern bowed instrument *[[Dapaqin]] (大琶琴) – bass ''paqin'' *[[Dixianqin]] (低絃琴)-also called yihu (一胡) a bowed monochord tuned to C3 *[[Niutuiqin]] or ''niubatui'' (牛腿琴 or 牛巴腿) – two-stringed fiddle used by the Dong people of Guizhou *[[Morin khuur|Matouqin]] (馬頭琴) – (Mongolian: ''[[morin khuur]]'') – Mongolian two-stringed "horsehead fiddle" *[[Xiqin (instrument)|Xiqin]] (奚琴) – ancient prototype of ''huqin'' family of instruments *[[Yazheng]] (simplified: 轧筝; traditional: 軋箏) – bowed zither; also called ''yaqin'' (simplified: 轧琴; traditional: 軋琴) *[[Zhengni]] (筝尼) – bowed zither; used by the [[Zhuang people]] of [[Guangxi]]<!--material for Zhengni article, when it's created: also called 瓦琴,唐琴,福琴,梧桐琴, and 七弦琴--> *[[Ghaychak]] ([[wikt:艾捷克|艾捷克]]) – four-stringed bowed instrument used in Uyghur traditional music of Xinjiang; similar to ''[[kamancheh]]'' [https://web.archive.org/web/20061212102347/http://www.chinamedley.com/langyuan/aijieke/] *[[Sataer]] ([[wikt:萨塔尔|萨塔尔]] or [[wikt:萨它尔|萨它尔]]) – long-necked bowed lute with 13 strings used in Uyghur traditional music of Xinjiang. 1 playing string and 12 sympathetic strings. *[[Khushtar]] ([[wikt:胡西它尔|胡西它尔]]) – a four-stringed bowed instrument used in Uyghur traditional music of Xinjiang
===Struck=== *[[Yangqin]] ([[wikt:揚琴|揚琴]]) – hammered dulcimer *[[Zhu (string instrument)|Zhu]] ([[wikt:筑|筑]]) – a zither similar to a guzheng but it's played with a bamboo mallet *[[Niujinqin]] ([[wikt:牛筋琴|牛筋琴]]) – a zither used to accompany traditional narrative singing in [[Wenzhou]], [[Zhejiang]] province, China. Similar to a guqin but played with a bamboo mallet.
==Bamboo ([[wikt:竹|竹]])== [[Image:Gu Hongzhong's Night Revels 2.jpg|thumb|right|500px|A half-section of the [[Song Dynasty]] (960–1279) version of the ''Night Revels of Han Xizai'', original by [[Gu Hongzhong]];<ref name="ebrey cambridge 148">Patricia Ebrey (1999), ''Cambridge Illustrated History of China'', Cambridge: Cambridge University Press, p. 148.</ref> the female musicians in the center of the image are playing [[Dizi (musical instrument)|transverse bamboo flutes]] and ''[[Guan (instrument)|guan]]'', and the male musician is playing a wooden clapper called ''paiban''.]]
[[Image:Bawuphoto.jpg|thumb|right|200px|A [[Bawu]] in the key of F<ref>[[Bawu|Bawu Wikipage]]</ref>]]
Bamboo mainly refers to woodwind instruments, which includes;
===Flutes=== *[[Dizi (musical instrument)|Dizi]] ([[wikt:笛子|笛子]]) – transverse bamboo flute with buzzing membrane **[[Bangdi]] (梆笛) *[[Xiao (flute)|Xiao]] ({{zh|t=[[wikt:簫|簫]]|s=[[wikt:箫|箫]]}}; pinyin: xiāo) – end-blown flute; also called ''dongxiao'' ({{zh|t=[[wiktionary:洞簫|洞簫]]|s=[[wiktionary:洞箫|洞箫]]}}) *[[Paixiao]] ({{zh|t=[[wikt:排簫|排簫]]|s=[[wikt:排箫|排箫]]}}; pinyin: páixiāo) – [[pan pipes]] *[[Chi (instrument)|Chi]] ([[wikt:篪|篪]]; pinyin: chí) – ancient transverse bamboo flute *[[Yue (instrument)|Yue]] ([[wiktionary:籥|籥]]; pinyin: yuè) – ancient notched vertical bamboo flute with three finger holes; used in Confucian ritual music and dance *[[Xindi (Chinese Instrument)|Xindi]] (新笛) – modern transverse flute with as many as 21 holes *[[Dongdi]] (侗笛) – wind instrument of the [[Dong people]] of southern China *[[Koudi]] ([[wikt:口笛|口笛]]; pinyin: kǒudí) – very small transverse bamboo flute
===Free reed pipes=== *[[Bawu]] ({{zh|t=[[wikt:巴烏|巴烏]]|s=[[wikt:巴乌|巴乌]]|p=bāwū}}) – side-blown free reed pipe with finger holes *[[Mangtong]] ([[wiktionary:芒筒|芒筒]]; pinyin: mángtǒng) – end-blown free reed pipe producing a single pitch *[[Miaozu di]] ({{zh|t=[[wikt:苗族笛|苗族笛]]|p= miáozú dí}}
===Single reed pipes=== *[[Mabu (instrument)|Mabu]] ([[wikt:马布|马布]]) – single-reed bamboo pipe played by the [[Yi people]]
===Double reed pipes=== *[[Guan (instrument)|Guan]] ({{zh|c=[[wikt:管|管]]|p=guǎn}}) – cylindrical [[double reed]] wind instrument made of either hardwood (Northern China) or bamboo (Cantonese); the northern version is also called ''guanzi'' ([[wikt:管子|管子]]) or ''bili'' (traditional: [[wikt:篳篥|篳篥]]; simplified: [[wikt:筚篥|筚篥]]), the Cantonese version is also called ''houguan'' ([[wikt:喉管|喉管]]), and the Taiwanese version is called 鸭母哒仔,<!--need romanization--> 鴨母笛,<!--need romanization--> or ''Taiwan guan'' (台湾管) *[[Suona]] ({{zh|t=[[wikt:嗩吶|嗩吶]]|s=[[wikt:唢呐|唢呐]]}}) – double-reed wind instrument with a flaring metal bell; also called ''haidi'' ([[wikt:海笛|海笛]]) *[[Haotong]]
==Wood ([[wikt:木|木]])== Most wood instruments are of the ancient variety:
*[[Zhu (percussion instrument)|Zhu]] ({{zh|c=[[wikt:柷|柷]]|p=zhù}}) – a wooden box that tapers from the top to the bottom, played by hitting a stick on the inside, used to mark the beginning of music in ancient ritual music *[[Yu (percussion instrument)|Yu]] ({{zh|c=[[wikt:敔|敔]]|p=yǔ}}) – a wooden percussion instrument carved in the shape of a tiger with a serrated back, played by hitting a stick with an end made of approximately 15 stalks of bamboo on its head three times and across the serrated back once to mark the end of the music *[[Wooden fish|Muyu]] ({{zh|t=[[wikt:木魚|木魚]]|s=[[wikt:木鱼|木鱼]]|p=mùyú}}) – a rounded woodblock carved in the shape of a fish, struck with a wooden stick; often used in Buddhist chanting [[File:Chinese Muyu QM r.jpg|right|thumb|This is a set of muyus or Chinese wooden slit drums. The sound produced is affected by the instrument’s size, type of wood, and how hollow it is.]] *[[Paiban]] ([[wikt:拍板|拍板]]) – a clapper made from several flat pieces of wood; also called ''bǎn'' (板), ''tánbǎn'' (檀板), ''mùbǎn'' (木板), or ''shūbǎn'' (书板); when used together with a drum the two instruments are referred to collectively as ''[[Guban (instrument)|guban]]'' ([[wikt:鼓板|鼓板]]) **Ban (''Chinese Langguage'') **Zhuban (竹板, a clapper made from two pieces of bamboo) **Chiban (尺板)<!--romanization needs to be checked; needs description--> *[[Bangzi]] ([[wikt:梆子|梆子]]) – small, high-pitched [[Wood block|woodblock]]; called ''qiaozi'' (敲子) or ''qiaoziban'' (敲子板) in Taiwan **Nan bangzi (南梆子) **Hebei bangzi (河北梆子) **Zhui bangzi (墜梆子) **Qin bangzi (秦梆子)
==Stone ([[wikt:石|石]])== The "stone" category comprises various forms of stone chimes. *[[Bianqing]] ({{zh|t=[[wikt:編磬|編磬]]|s=[[wikt:编磬|编磬]]|p=biānqìng}}) – a rack of stone tablets that are hung by ropes from a wooden frame and struck using a mallet *[[Tezhong]] (特鐘) – a single large stone tablet hung by a rope in a wooden frame and struck using a mallet *[[Sounding stone]] or [[Qing]] (磬)
==Metal ([[wikt:金|金]])== *[[Bianzhong]] ([[wikt:編鐘|編鐘]]) – 16 to 65<!--are these numbers correct?--> bronze bells hung on a rack, struck using poles *[[Fangxiang]] ({{zh|t=方響|s=方响|p=fāngxiǎng|w=fang hsiang}}) – set of tuned metal slabs ([[metallophone]]) *[[Nao (musical instrument)]] ([[wikt:鐃|鐃]]) – may refer to either an ancient bell or large cymbals **[[Shangnao]] (商鐃) – ancient bell<sup>[http://images.china.cn/attachement/jpg/site1000/20080226/000802e406ec092db1c005.jpg photo]</sup> *[[Bo (instrument)|Bo]] ([[wikt:鈸|鈸]]; also called ''chazi'', [[wikt:镲子|镲子]]) – **Xiaobo (小鈸, small cymbals)<!--needs description--> **Zhongbo (中鈸, medium cymbals; also called ''naobo'' (鐃鈸) or ''zhongcuo''<!--need hanzi--><!--needs description--> **Shuibo (水鈸, literally "water cymbals")<!--needs description--> **Dabo (大鈸, large cymbals)<!--needs description--> **Jingbo (京鈸)<!--needs description--> **Shenbo (深波) – deep, flat gong used in Chaozhou music; also called ''gaobian daluo'' (高边大锣) *[[Luo (instrument)|Luo]] ({{zh|t=[[wiktionary:鑼|鑼]]|s=[[wikt:锣|锣]]}}; pinyin: luó) – [[gong]] **[[Daluo]] (大锣) – a large flat gong whose pitch drops when struck with a padded mallet **[[Fengluo]] (风锣) – literally "wind gong," a large flat gong played by rolling or striking with a large padded mallet **[[Xiaoluo]] (小锣) – a small flat gong whose pitch rises when struck with the side of a flat wooden stick **Yueluo (月锣) – small pitched gong held by a string in the palm of the hand and struck with a small stick; used in Chaozhou music **Jingluo (镜锣) – a small flat gong used in the traditional music of Fujian [http://www.fj.xinhuanet.com/jlzx/2007-09/13/content_11135856.htm] **[[Pingluo]] (平锣) – a flat gong<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.kitde.com.tw/jane/pic/031-07.jpg|title=photo|publisher=|accessdate=8 April 2018}}</ref> **[[Kailuluo]] (开路锣)<!--needs description; romanization needs to be checked--> *[[Yunluo]] ({{zh|t=[[wiktionary:雲鑼|雲鑼]]|s=[[wikt:云锣|云锣]]}}) – literally "cloud gongs"; 10 or more small tuned gongs in a frame *[[Shimianluo]] ([[wikt:十面锣|十面锣]]) – 10 small tuned gongs in a frame *[[Sounding stone|Qing]] ([[wikt:磬|磬]]) – a cup-shaped bell used in Buddhist and Daoist ritual music *Daqing (大磬) – large ''qing'' *[[Pengling]] ([[wikt:碰铃|碰铃]]; pinyin: pènglíng) – a pair of small bowl-shaped finger cymbals or bells connected by a length of cord, which are struck together *[[Dangzi (instrument)|Dangzi]] ([[wikt:铛子|铛子]]) – a small, round, flat, tuned gong suspended by being tied with silk string in a round metal frame that is mounted on a thin wooden handle<sup>[http://www.oknation.net/blog/home/blog_data/335/335/images/4.jpg photo]</sup>; also called ''dangdang'' (铛铛) *[[Yinqing]] (引磬) – an inverted small bell affixed to the end of a thin wooden handle<sup>[http://nrch.cca.gov.tw/metadataserverDevp/DOFiles/jpg/00/05/68/56/cca200112-an-00344-0001-i.jpg photo]</sup> *[[Yunzheng]] (云铮) – a small flat gong used in the traditional music of Fujian [http://www.fj.xinhuanet.com/jlzx/2007-09/13/content_11135856.htm] *[[Chun (musical instrument)|Chun]] ([[wikt:錞|錞]]; pinyin: chún) – ancient bell<sup>[http://www.cq.xinhuanet.com/2006-09/20/xin_030903201046687401111.jpg photo]</sup> **[[Weichun]] ([[wikt:帷|帷]][[wikt:錞|錞]]) – ancient hanging bell *[[Dong son drum|Bronze drum]] ([[wikt:铜鼓|铜鼓]]) *[[Suona|Laba]] ([[wiktionary:喇叭|喇叭]]) – A long, straight, valveless brass trumpet<!--can this also be called 大杆号?-->
==Clay ([[wikt:土|土]])== *[[Xun (instrument)|Xun]] ([[wikt:埙|埙]], {{zh|c=[[wiktionary:塤|塤]]|p=xūn}}) – [[ocarina]] made of baked clay *[[Fou (instrument)|Fou]] ({{zh|c=[[wiktionary:缶|缶]]|p=fǒu}}) – clay pot played as a percussion instrument
==Gourd ([[wikt:匏|匏]])== *[[Sheng (instrument)|Sheng]] ({{zh|c=[[wikt:笙|笙]]|p=shēng}}) – free reed mouth organ consisting of varying number of bamboo pipes inserted into a metal (formerly gourd or hardwood) chamber with finger holes **Baosheng (抱笙) – larger version of the Sheng *[[Yu (wind instrument)|Yu]] ({{zh|c=[[wikt:竽|竽]]|p=yú}}) – ancient free reed mouth organ similar to the sheng but generally larger *[[He (wind instrument)|He]] ({{zh|c=[[wikt:和|和]]|p=he}})<!--need tone--> – ancient free reed mouth organ similar to the sheng but smaller *[[Hulusi]] ({{zh|t=[[wikt:葫蘆絲|葫蘆絲]]|s=[[wikt:葫芦丝|葫芦丝]]}}; pinyin: húlúsī) – free-reed wind instrument with three bamboo pipes which pass through a gourd wind chest; one pipe has finger holes and the other two are drone pipes; used primarily in [[Yunnan]] province *[[Hulusheng]] ({{zh|t=[[wikt:葫蘆笙|葫蘆笙]]|s=[[wikt:葫芦笙|葫芦笙]]}}; pinyin: húlúshēng) – free-reed mouth organ with a gourd wind chest; used primarily in [[Yunnan]] province *[[Fangsheng]] – Northern China Gourd
==Skin ([[wikt:革|革]])== [[File:Chaozhou large drum 20060218.jpg|thumb|right|220px|A Chaozhou ''dagu'' (large drum)]] [[File:Bolang-gu-chinese-instrument.jpg|thumb|right|220px|A Chinese ''Bolang Gu''<ref>[http://www.virtualvillage.com/beggar-s-drum-percussion-instrument-009007-005.html Chinese Musical Instrument-Bolanggu]</ref>]] *[[Dagu (instrument)|Dagu]] – ([[wikt:大鼓|大鼓]]) – large drum played with two sticks **[[Huapengu]] ([[wikt:花盆鼓|花盆鼓]]) – [[flowerpot]]-shaped large drum played with two sticks; also called ''ganggu'' (缸鼓) *[[Huzuo Dagu]] (虎座大鼓) *[[Huzuo Wujia Gu]] (虎座鳥架鼓) *[[Jian'gu]] (建鼓) *[[Bangu (drum)|Bangu]] ([[wikt:板鼓|板鼓]]) – small, high pitched drum used in Beijing opera; also called ''danpigu'' ([[wikt:单皮鼓|单皮鼓]]) *[[Biangu]] ([[wikt:扁|扁]][[wikt:鼓|鼓]]) – flat drum, played with sticks *[[Paigu]] ([[wikt:排鼓|排鼓]]) – set of three to seven tuned drums played with sticks *[[Tanggu (drum)|Tanggu]] ([[wikt:堂鼓|堂鼓]]) – medium-sized barrel drum played with two sticks; also called ''tonggu'' (同鼓) or ''xiaogu'' (小鼓) *[[Biqigu]] (荸荠鼓) – a very small drum played with one stick, used in [[Jiangnan sizhu]]<!--is the literal meaning "chestnut drum"?--> *[[Diangu]] (点鼓; also called ''huaigu'', 怀鼓) – a double-headed [[frame drum]] played with a single wooden beater; used in the Shifangu ensemble music of Jiangsu province and to accompany to ''[[kunqu]]'' opera *[[Huagu]] (花鼓) – flower drum *[[Yaogu]] (腰鼓) – waist drum *[[Taipinggu]] (太平鼓) – flat drum with a handle; also called ''dangu'' (单鼓) *[[Zhangu]] (战鼓 or 戰鼓) – war drum; played with two sticks *[[Bajiao gu]] ([[wikt:八角鼓|八角鼓]]) – octagonal tambourine used primarily in narrative singing from northern China [[:zh:八角鼓]] *[[Yanggegu]] (秧歌鼓) – rice planting drum *[[Gaogu]] ({{linktext|鼛鼓}}) – large ancient drum used to for battlefield commands and large-scale construction *[[Bofu]] ([[wikt:搏拊|搏拊]]) – ancient drum used to set tempo *[[Jiegu]] ([[wikt:羯鼓|羯鼓]]) – hourglass-shaped drum used during the Tang Dynasty *[[Tao (drum)|Tao]] ([[wikt:鼗|鼗]]; pinyin: táo) or ''taogu'' (鼗鼓) – a [[pellet drum]] used in ritual music *[[Bolang Gu]] (波浪鼓；pinyin: bo lang gu) – a traditional Chinese [[pellet drum]] and [[toy]]
==Others== *[[Gudi (instrument)|Gudi]] ([[wikt:骨笛|骨笛]]) – an ancient flute made of bone<ref>{{citation|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ERnrQq0bsPYC&pg=PA694|year=2000| title=Chinese history|isbn=978-0-674-00249-4 |author=Endymion Wilkinson|authorlink=Endymion Wilkinson}}</ref> *[[Hailuo]] ([[wikt:海螺|海螺]]) – conch shell [http://2007jzj.gzwh.gov.cn/yyzs/2005zgyq/zgyq.asp?id=21] *[[Lilie (instrument)|Lilie]] (唎咧) – reed wind instrument with a conical bore played by the [[Li people]] of [[Hainan]] *[[Lusheng]] ({{zh|t=蘆笙|s=芦笙}}; pinyin: lúshēng) – free-reed mouth organ with five or six pipes, played by various ethnic groups in southwest China and neighboring countries *[[Kouxian]] ([[wikt:口弦|口弦]]) – [[jaw harp]], made of bamboo or metal *Muye (木叶) – tree leaf used as a wind instrument
==Playing contexts== Chinese instruments are either played solo, collectively in large orchestras (as in the former imperial court) or in smaller ensembles (in teahouses or public gatherings). Normally, there is no conductor in traditional Chinese music, nor any use of musical scores or tablature in performance. Music was generally learned aurally and memorized by the musician(s) beforehand, then played without aid. As of the 20th century, musical scores have become more common, as has the use of conductors in larger orchestral-type ensembles.
==Musical instruments in use in the 1800s== These watercolour illustrations, made in China in the 1800s, show several types of musical instruments being played:
<gallery> File:Playing a dizi.jpg|Woman playing a dizi. File:Playing a jinghu.jpg|Woman playing a jinghu. File:Playing a luo.jpg|Woman playing a luo. File:Playing a pipa.jpg|Woman playing a pipa. File:Playing a sanxian.jpg|Woman playing a sanxian. File:Playing a shimianluo.jpg|Woman playing a shimianluo. File:Playing a small drum.jpg|Woman playing a xiaoluo. File:Playing a wind instrument with a curved bell.jpg|Woman playing a wind instrument with a haotou. File:Playing a xiao.jpg|Woman playing a xiao. File:Playing a zheng.jpg|Woman playing what looks like a yangqin or some sort of psaltery-like instrument. </gallery>
==See also== *[[Music of China]] *[[Traditional Korean musical instruments]] *[[Chinese art]] *[[Chinese instrument classification]] *[[List of ensemble formations in traditional Chinese music]]
==References== ;Notes {{Reflist}} ;Sources *Lee, Yuan-Yuan and Shen, Sinyan. ''Chinese Musical Instruments (Chinese Music Monograph Series)''. 1999. Chinese Music Society of North America Press. {{ISBN|1-880464-03-9}} *Shen, Sinyan. ''Chinese Music in the 20th Century (Chinese Music Monograph Series)''. 2001. Chinese Music Society of North America Press. {{ISBN|1-880464-04-7}} *Yuan, Bingchang, and Jizeng Mao (1986). ''Zhongguo Shao Shu Min Zu Yue Qi Zhi''. Beijing: Xin Shi Jie Chu Ban She/Xin Hua Shu Dian Beijing Fa Xing Suo Fa Xing. {{ISBN|7-80005-017-3}}.
==External links== *[http://2007jzj.gzwh.gov.cn/yyzs/index.asp Chinese musical instruments] *[http://www.lcsd.gov.hk/CE/CulturalService/MusicOffice/intro_music/chi_eng_main.html Chinese Musical Instruments] Leisure and Cultural Services Department, Hong Kong *[http://www.chime.com.cn Chime] A look at ancient Chinese instruments *[http://www.e56.com.cn/minzu/Musical/Musical_main.asp Chinese musical instruments] (Chinese) *[http://www.chineseinstruments.org Chinese Instruments Website] (English) *[http://www.chinakongzi.com/2550/eng/music/yq/index.htm Chinese musical instruments] *[http://resources.edb.gov.hk/musiceb/ The Musical Instruments E-book] *[http://www.woim.net/ World of Instrumental Music] *[http://www.chinesisches-neujahrskonzert.de/en/home.html The Grand Chinese New Year Concert] *[https://www.google.com/images?hl=en&q=chinese+instrument&um=1&ie=UTF-8&source=univ&ei=AjsPTOfqKI_yMpjvkc0M&sa=X&oi=image_result_group&ct=title&resnum=1&ved=0CBEQsAQwAA Chinese Instrument] *[http://www.virtualvillage.com/oriental-instruments Chinese Musical Instruments] (The Modern Appearance) *https://www.britannica.com/art/qin-musical-instrument

revision.comment: Rescuing 1 sources and tagging 0 as dead. #IABot (v1.6.2)
revision.text:
{{more footnotes|date=January 2015}} The '''National Center of Afro-American Artists''' ('''NCAAA''') is an institution founded in 1968 by [[Elma Lewis]] to "preserv[e] and foster[] the cultural arts heritage of black peoples worldwide through arts teaching, and the presentation of professional works in all fine arts disciplines."<ref name="NCAAA History">[http://www.ncaaa.org/ncaaahistory.html NCAAA History] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141122083554/http://www.ncaaa.org/ncaaahistory.html |date=2014-11-22 }}</ref> Although the organization's name specifies [[African American]] artists, the organizational mandate includes all [[African art|African diasporic art]].
The [[museum]] subsumed Lewis' previously launched "Elma Lewis School of Fine Arts" (ELSFA). The NCAAA is the largest independent black cultural arts institution in [[New England]], United States.
At its founding, the NCAAA was housed in a former [[fire station|firehouse]] in [[Franklin Park (Boston)|Franklin Park]], [[Boston]]. The museum was moved to a separate building in 1980 and is now located at the '''[[Abbotsford (Boston, Massachusetts)|Museum of the National Center of Afro-American Artists]]'''.
Two fires in the early 1980s significantly damaged the firehouse, where the NCAAA was housed, although collections stored at the museum, which had its own facility, were unharmed.<ref name="NCAAA History"/>
Activities of the NCAAA have included:
* Establishment and maintenance of a museum; * Hosting arts performances ("Black Musical Productions" and others) and exhibitions, individually and in collaboration with other fine arts museums in Boston; * Offering arts education programs to a variety of students (professional, community primary students, and local prisoners).
[[Harriet Forte Kennedy]] served as the assistant director of the museum for some time.<ref name="HellerHeller2013">{{cite book|author1=Jules Heller|author2=Nancy G. Heller|title=North American Women Artists of the Twentieth Century: A Biographical Dictionary|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=AYxmAgAAQBAJ&pg=PR11|date=19 December 2013|publisher=Routledge|isbn=978-1-135-63882-5}}</ref> ==Notes== {{reflist}}
==External links== * [http://www.ncaaa.org/ NCAAA website] *The [http://www.library.neu.edu/archives/collect/findaids/m38find.htm Elma Ina Lewis papers, 1917-1998] are located in the Northeastern University Libraries, Archives and Special Collections Department, Boston, MA. *The [http://www.library.neu.edu/archives/collect/findaids/m43find.htm Elma Lewis School of Fine Arts records, 1954-1992] are located in the Northeastern University Libraries, Archives and Special Collections Department, Boston, MA. *The [http://www.library.neu.edu/archives/collect/findaids/m42find.htm National Center of Afro–American Artists records 1924–1998] are located in the Northeastern University Libraries, Archives and Special Collections Department, Boston, MA. *The [http://www.library.neu.edu/archives/collect/findaids/m44find.htm Museum of the National Center of Afro-American Artists records, 1966-1998] are located in the Northeastern University Libraries, Archives and Special Collections Department, Boston, MA.
[[Category:Arts organizations established in 1968]] [[Category:Arts centers in Massachusetts]] [[Category:African-American arts organizations]] [[Category:Organizations based in Boston]] [[Category:Art museums established in 1968]] [[Category:1968 establishments in Massachusetts]]

revision.text:
{{Multiple issues| {{no footnotes|date=April 2015}} {{refimprove|date=April 2015}} }}
'''Neosymbolism''' is a movement current in the [[visual arts]] genre. Active in the movement are artists in the United States, Denmark, the [[Czech Republic]], and Canada.
== Philosophy == The core philosophy of Neosymbolism, like that of its predecessor [[Symbolism (arts)|Symbolism]], is the idea of "correspondences", the "emblematic order" of a world in which technology and the industrial reality have not yet drowned the forces of mysticism and belief. In a world where visual images exist to generate sales and revenue, Neosymbolist imagery attempts to preserve the relationship between image and the human soul. The imagery is necessarily representational rather than abstract. It borders on the narrative, but stops short of the commercial trap of illustration to convey an idea for profit. Artists like [[Norman Rockwell]] could qualify as Neosymbolist painters in that they adopt a social and cultural undercurrent and then convey it in terms of the cultural cliche—the image as representative of core aspects of the culture. The same is not true, however, of the generally accepted idea of commercial illustration which attempts more to influence cultural, political, and economic ideology than it tries to communicate an existential reality.
Neosymbolism is fairly well-hidden within the culture, with few references and almost no broad-based visibility. In 1988, Nick A_Demos published a book in two editions. This was the first visible sign of an idea underlying a Neosymbolist philosophy. A_Demos then developed this first book of Neosymbolism into paintings. He was also the first to use the word "Neosymbolism", thus coining it.{{citation needed|date=April 2015}}
There has also been a separate group using the Neosymbolism name for the creation of an international collective representing a number of artists who share the goals of preserving the visual art of Symbolism (the foundation of the ideas associated with the term Neosymbolism) in its original and essential sense. This preservation, as opposed to the "non-sense" of various philosophies that have evolved since the late nineteenth century and have deviated from the core Symbolist philosophy.
The Neosymbolist movement was born spontaneously in numerous locations across the globe. Many groups use the word but also do not want to be limited to only this discipline. A group of Danish Neosymbolists defined their movement thus:<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.arrkunst.webbyen.dk/vishjemmeside_privat.asp?mode=top_frame&id=614394&side=&webside=4222305 |title=webbyen.dk |date=2011-07-19 |access-date=2017-02-07 |deadurl=bot: unknown |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110719132848/http://www.arrkunst.webbyen.dk/vishjemmeside_privat.asp?mode=top_frame&id=614394&side=&webside=4222305 |archivedate=2011-07-19 |df= }}</ref>
* Using Iconic language in their expressions * Reproducing the inner experience of the outer world * Examining the human experience and circumstance in today’s changing world * Examining the underlying meaning of life * Using media in conscious and innovative ways
The founder of the Canadian Neosymbolists, meanwhile, describes the foundations of their movement in ''Brief Summary of the Foundations of Canadian Neosymbolism,''{{citation needed|date=April 2015}} written by their founder, Gary F. Manzo.
* Using Symbolic language in our expressions, often derived from Dream Sequences and Archetypal Imagery as described by Carl Jung, and others involved with Mysticism, Alchemy, Depth Psychology and Philosophy. * Depicting the inner experience of the outer world, in relationship to Self-Actualization and Depth Psychology and related fields of study. * Examining the human experience and circumstance in today’s changing world, with the idea that mankind must “make friends with his animal nature” in order to achieve Wholeness of SELF in a contemporary world. * Examining the underlying meaning of life, both from an historical perspective and its relevancy to the new age of Technology as well as New Age Psychology. * Using mediums and techniques, in conscious, experimental and innovative ways, utilizing both traditional methods and contemporary cutting-edge techniques and technologies.
Another international Neosymbolist collective that began exhibiting as a group in 2001 has a simpler definition:
- The "exploration of the emotional, political, and spiritual themes of the rapidly changing culture of the late 20th and early 21st (century) through the use of symbols both personal and universal."{{cite quote|date=April 2015}}
This perspective of the Neosymbolist movement can be seen as a reaction against abstraction, an attempt to weave artists’ intellectual and spiritual experiences into the fabric of their work. Furthermore, the Neosymbolists’ palette is not limited to the use of words and ancient symbols of ideas, even as these remain powerful tools of expression.{{citation needed|date=April 2015}}
==Reviews== The exhibition history of these groups, including their collaborations with the Danish Neosymbolist collective, are documented in reviews in the following periodicals. More information about this group can also be found at www.neosymbolism.eu
* ''Sketch Book, the Artists’ Coalition of Austin'' ''Newsletter'' * Pascale Vial, July 2001, "Neosymbolismus at Depot St. Gallery" * Jacqueline May, May 7, 2004, ''[[The Austin Chronicle|Austin Chronicle]]'', Vol 23, No. 26 * Gabriela Garbova - March 17, 2005, ''Olomoucky Den'' * "The Exhibition of Neosymbolist Art", ''Austin Gazeta'', October, 2006 * Af Michael Friis, November 22, 2006, "Symbol X i Rahuset", ''Vesterbro Bladet'', Copenhagen, Denmark * "Galerii Osadil Neosymbolismus", ''[[Bulgaria Dnes|Dnes]]'', January 5, 2007 * Vlasta Hrdilova, January 12, 2007, "Neosymboliste Vystavuji v Olomouci", ''Pravo'' * Ondrej Grezdo, Octobra 14, 2008, "Americki vytarnici predstavili neosymbolizmus", ''Piestansky Tyzden''
==References== {{reflist}}
== External links == *[http://www.neosymbolism.eu NEOSYMBOLISM.eu]
[[Category:Art movements]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox artwork | title = Nomoli | painting_alignment = Center | other_language_1 = | other_title_1 = | other_language_2 = | other_title_2 = | wikidata = | image = Nomoli-Mende-Sierra Leone.jpg | image_upright = | alt = Nomoli Sierra Leone | caption = A Nomoli figurine. | artist = | year = circa 1500s | completion_date = <!-- For a more specific date (post-1583): {{start date|YYYY|MM|DD|df=y}} --> | catalogue = | medium = [[Soapstone]] | movement = | subject = | height_metric = 17 | width_metric = 10.2 | length_metric = | diameter_metric = 9 | height_imperial = <!-- (i.e. in imperial units) --> | width_imperial = | length_imperial = | diameter_imperial = | dimensions = | dimensions_ref = | metric_unit = cm <!-- Note: this parameter must either use the value given or not be included --> | imperial_unit = in <!-- Note: this parameter must either use the value given or not be included --> | weight = 1597 grams | designation = | condition = | museum = [[Musée du quai Branly – Jacques Chirac]] | city = [[Paris]], [[France]] | coordinates = <!-- Only use for the coordinates (when known) of the artwork itself, i.e. not for the site, building, structure, etc where it is kept, otherwise leave blank (or omit): {{coord|LAT|LON|type:landmark|display=inline,title}} --> | owner = | accession = | preceded_by = <!-- preceding work by the same artist --> | followed_by = <!-- next work by the same artist --> | module = | website = {{URL|http://www.quaibranly.fr}} }}
A '''Nomoli''' ({{IPAc-en|ˈ|n|oʊ|m|oʊ|l|iː}}) is a carved stone figurine native to [[Sierra Leone]] and [[Liberia]].<ref name="Smithsonian">{{Cite web |url=https://africa.si.edu/collections/view/objects/asitem/People$00401633/2/title-asc?t:state:flow=3d318f72-8617-4bde-ba1f-b19ed158e54b |title=National Museum of African Art |website=africa.si.edu |access-date=2018-06-29}}</ref> They are usually made of [[soapstone]], [[limestone]] or [[granite]].<ref name="Smithsonian" /><ref name="British Museum">{{Cite web |url=http://www.britishmuseum.org/research/collection_online/collection_object_details.aspx?objectId=628044&partId=1 |title=nomoli figure |website=British Museum |language=en-GB |access-date=2018-06-29}}</ref>
==Origins== Nomoli figurines are among the earliest works of art from [[Sierra Leone]].<ref name="Emory">{{Cite web |url=http://carlos.emory.edu/exhibits/show/home/item/8011 |title=Figure, Pomdo or Nomoli · Michael C. Carlos Museum Collections Online |website=carlos.emory.edu |language=en-US |access-date=2018-06-29}}</ref> The Nomoli figurines and similar stone sculptures are the only known remains of an empire that existed hundreds of years ago in what is [[Sierra Leone]] and [[Liberia]] today.
Nomoli figurines are often associated with the [[Mende people|Mende]] people as they are often buried on [[Mende people|Mende]] land. They are used as oracles and for protection.<ref name="Emory" />
Portuguese explorers recorded the presence of the figurines already in the fifteenth century.<ref name="Smithsonian" />
The Mende and [[Kissi people]] of Sierra Leone put these small statues near their homes and in fields of crops for protection and increased vegetation, as they believe the Nomoli figurines will give them good health, good harvest, and meals to eat.<ref name="Emory" />
During the 20th century, Sierra Leonean immigrants brought their [[ancestor]]’s Nomoli figurines with them to the United States as a way to preserve the spiritual powers of the past.
== Characteristics and description == Along the coastal region, Nomoli figurines are often carved into a crouching stance with a small object in its hands. Most Nomoli figurines are made out of [[soapstone]], [[limestone]], steatite, and in some cases, [[granite]].
Their heads are oblong shaped. Nomoli figurines buried deeper underground tend to be more well preserved than the ones discovered just beneath the surface of the earth.
==References== <references/>
==Further reading== *[https://books.google.com/books?id=XaWpDgAAQBAJ&lpg=PA921&dq=nomoli%20figurines&pg=PA153#v=onepage&q=nomoli%20figurines&f=false Oxford Handbook of Prehistoric Figurines]
[[Category:Figurines]] [[Category:African art]] [[Category:Sierra Leonean art]] [[Category:History of Sierra Leone]]
{{Subject bar |portal1= Africa |portal2= Art |portal3= Sierra Leone}}

{{IPA notice}} '''''Orihon''''' ([[Japanese language|Japanese]]: 折本, [[Hepburn Romanization| Hepburn]]: Orihon, {{IPA-ja|oɾihoɴ}}) is a book style originating from the Tang dynasty (A.D. 618-908) in China and was later developed in the Heian period (A.D. 794-1185) in Japan.<ref>Binding Beauty: Conserving a Collection of Japanese Printed Books Barbara Korbel and Janice Katz Art Institute of Chicago Museum Studies Vol. 31, No. 2, Conservation at the Art Institute of Chicago (2005), pp. 16-23+105</ref>
== History == [[File:Livre-eventail-Japon.jpg|320px|right|Livre-eventail-Japon]]The development of orihon began in China but later took on an association with [[Japanese books]], as shown by its current name. "The development of alternatives to the roll in China is difficult to date, but it appears that at some time during the Tang period long rolls consisting of sheets of paper pasted together began to be folded alternately one way and the other to produce an effect like a concertina. It has been supposed that this form was suggested by the palm-leaf books which transmitted Buddhist texts from India to China. However that may be, it is in any case a fact that the concertina form was primarily used in China, and subsequently in Japan, for Buddhist texts. Books of this format are called orihon 折本 in Japan, and the format survived until the nineteenth century and beyond for printed Buddhist sūtras and occasionally for other books, such as reference lists, calendars, and folding maps."<ref>The Book in Japan: A Cultural History from the Beginnings to the Nineteenth Century by Peter Kornicki, p. 43. Retrieved from http://www.printsofjapan.com/Index_Glossary_O_thru_Ri.htm</ref> Laura C. Liberman notes in an article that the accordion book style used in Tibet traces back to orihon origins.<ref><Lieberman, Laura C. "The Robert C. Williams American Museum of Papermaking." JAB: The Journal of Artist's Books 15 (2001): 12-13. ProQuest. Web. 11 Mar. 2015.</ref>
=== Etymology === The combination of characters are borrowed from Chinese, which originally translates the phrase to "a loss" or "a loss of money." <ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.purpleculture.net/dictionary_details/?word=折本|title = Chinese Word - 折本|date = |accessdate = |website = |publisher = |last = |first = }}</ref> However, when looking at the individual characters, a different meaning is found. The Traditional Chinese characters are defined as 折 meaning "to break (e.g. stick or bone); a loss"<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.purpleculture.net/dictionary-details/?word=折|title = Meaning of 折|date = |accessdate = |website = |publisher = |last = |first = }}</ref> and 本 meaning "roots or stems of plants; origin; source; this; the current; root; foundation; basis; classifier for books, periodicals, files etc originally,"<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.purpleculture.net/dictionary-details/?word=本|title = Meaning of 本|date = |accessdate = |website = |publisher = |last = |first = }}</ref> In this context, it means a breakdown of a book. In Japanese, it combines the roots "ori" (fold) and "hon" (book).<ref>http://www.wordsense.eu/本/</ref> Edith Diehl describes orihon as a general Asian style and translates it to "stabbed binding."<ref>Diehl, Edith. "Primative Records and Ancient Book Forms." Bookbinding; Its Background and Technique. New York: Rinehart &, 1946. 12. Print.</ref>
=== Uses === Cyril James Humphries Davenport notes in his 1898 lecture that "writing upon a roll was found to be the most convenient at a very early date by the Chinese, Japanese and [K]oreans, they were also the first to find out that if the rolls were simply folded backwards and forwards between the "pages" of writing or printing, the whole book became easier to read, and this form, known as "Orihon," is used in those countries to the present day."<ref>Davenport, Cyril. "Lecture 1." Cantor Lectures on Decorative Bookbinding. London: Printed by William Trounce, 10, Gough Square, Fleet Street, E.C., 1898. 2. Print.</ref>
Traditional orihon books are associated with Japanese Buddhist works and [[e-hon]], or picture books. Modern applications are found in artistic modes, such as Tom Burtonwood's 2013 plastic rendering using a 3-D printer.<ref>http://tomburtonwood.com/portfolio-item/orihon-3d-printed-book/</ref>
== Construction == <!-- Deleted image removed: [[File:Orihon-crop.png|framed|right|Utagawa Hiroshige (Japanese, 1797-1858) ''Sakkyo Kageboshi Zukushi'' (Collection of Improvised Silhouette Plays) n.d.]] -->Orihon consist of a long strip of paper that is written on one side and then compacted by folding in zig-zag fashion. The orihon format is considered a step between a [[scroll]] and a [[codex]].
The style of folding is similar to that of the air bellows of a [[concertina]] or [[accordion]], such that every written page faces another written page when the book is closed. It may therefore be opened to any page.<ref>https://art2551.files.wordpress.com/2011/10/book_demo.pdf</ref> It may have a cover attached to the front and back end sections of the book. Diehl describes orihon as having stabbed holes in the back cover to allow the book to be "laced."<ref>Diehl, Edith. "Primative Records and Ancient Book Forms." Bookbinding; Its Background and Technique. New York: Rinehart &, 1946. 12. Print.</ref>
==See also == *[[Folded leaflet#Concertina fold]]
== List of Orihon works == The Museum of Metropolitan Art in New York, New York hosts a collection of orihon art. Some of that work is available to view on [http://www.metmuseum.org/collection/the-collection-online/search?ft=orihon their website.] <ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.metmuseum.org/collection/the-collection-online/search?ft=orihon|title = Metropolitan Museum of Art Orihon Collection|date = |accessdate = |website = |publisher = |last = |first = }}</ref> * Utagawa Hiroshige (Japanese, 1797-1858) ''Sakkyo Kageboshi Zukushi'' (Collection of Improvised Silhouette Plays) n.d. * ''Onna Kasen'', an 18th-century book written about famous Japanese female poets.<ref>http://www.raco.cat/index.php/Datatextil/article/viewFile/274608/362870</ref> * 中山聘使畧 (''Chūzan heishi ryaku'' or ''Short account of the Ryūkyūan mission'') This book explains the history and geography of Ryūkyū.<ref>http://okinawa-repo.lib.u-ryukyu.ac.jp:8080/handle/okinawa/12729</ref> * Suzuki Harunobu (ca. 1724-70).'' A beauty watching a couple drinking sake, from The Spell of Amorous Love (Enshoku koi no urakata). ''Japan, circa 1766-70. Woodblock printed chuban orihon (folded illustrated book). 7.5 x 5.125 inches (19.2 x 13 cm). This piece is part of Asia Week New York's 2015 "gallery roster" for the "celebration for Asian Art" and is provided by Scholten Japanese Art from the United States as part of their exhibition ''Erotic Art of Japan: Everybody’s Doing It.''<ref>https://alaintruong2014.wordpress.com/tag/china-tibet/</ref>
== References == {{Reflist}}
[[Category:Books by type]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox artist | bgcolour = | name = Oscar Tuazon | image = | imagesize = | caption = | birth_name = | birth_date = 1975 | birth_place = | death_date = | death_place = | nationality = [[United States|American]] | field = [[Installation art]], [[Sculpture]] | training = [[Cooper Union]], Whitney ISP | movement = | works = | patrons = [[Charles Saatchi]] | influenced by = [[Vito Acconci]] | influenced = | awards = }} '''Oscar Tuazon''' (née Hansen) is an American artist based in Los Angeles who works in sculpture, architecture, and mixed media.
==Early life== Oscar Tuazon was born Oscar Hansen on July 9, 1975, in a geodesic dome his parents built in the woods at Indianola, [[Kitsap County, Washington]].<ref>http://www.historylink.org/File/10987</ref> He attended [[Deep Springs College]], [[Cooper Union]], and the Whitney Independent Study Program.<ref>[https://www.independent.co.uk/life-style/fashion/features/how-do-i-look-oscar-tuazon-artist-35-2008449.html How do I look?: Oscar Tuazon, artist, 35, [[The Independent]], June 26, 2010]</ref> In 2001 he served as a founding board member at the [[Center for Urban Pedagogy]] in New York with his former Deep Springs classmate [[Damon Rich]].<ref>[http://welcometocup.org/People Center for Urban Pedagogy: People, Accessed April 18, 2015]</ref><ref>[http://bombmagazine.org/article/5529/city-without-a-ghetto-center-for-urban-pedagogy "City Without a Ghetto, Center for Urban Pedagogy", Bomb Magazine Spring 2004]</ref>
Oscar met and married Lan Tuazon in New York in the mid-90s and changed his name from Oscar Hansen to Oscar Tuazon. The couple would later be divorced, but he kept the last name.<ref>http://www.historylink.org/File/10987</ref> His brother and frequent collaborator, Eli Hansen, is also an artist.<ref>http://www.seattlepi.com/ae/article/When-brothers-Eli-Hansen-and-Oscar-Tuazon-deliver-1271392.php</ref><ref>http://www.parcsaintleger.fr/en/portfolio/oscar-tuazon-eli-hansen/</ref>
==Career== Professionally, he began his career working in the Studio Acconci of architect/artist [[Vito Acconci]].<ref>[https://www.theguardian.com/artanddesign/2010/jul/28/artist-week-oscar-tuazon "Artist of the week 98: Oscar Tuazon," The Guardian, July 26, 2010]</ref> After moving to Paris in 2007, he began exhibiting widely in Europe.<ref>[http://www.vogue.fr/culture/agenda/articles/rencontre-avec-oscar-tuazon-la-biennale-de-venise-/19265 "Rencontre avec Oscar Tuazon à la Biennale de Venise," Paris Vogue]</ref> He has since then exhibited at the [[Venice Biennale]], the [[Whitney Biennial]], and many group and solo shows throughout the world, and is in major art collections such as Saatchi's.<ref>[http://www.thestranger.com/seattle/the-first-artists-on-the-waterfront/Content?oid=19141739 " The First Artists on the Waterfront," The Stranger, March 26, 2014]</ref><ref>[http://whitney.org/Exhibitions/2012Biennial/OscarTuazon 2012 Whitney Biennial Exhibitions] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150418142536/http://whitney.org/Exhibitions/2012Biennial/OscarTuazon |date=2015-04-18 }}</ref>
A critic in the art magazine [[Frieze]] wrote in 2013 that "like his heroes, from [[Gordon Matta-Clark]] to wilderness survivalists, Tuazon’s non-conformist approach to artistic practice plays at the juncture of architecture, sculpture and performance."<ref>[http://www.frieze.com/issue/review/oscar-tuazon/ "Oscar Tuazon," Frieze, April 2013]</ref> A [[New York Times]] review described his work as "haunting ... pit[ting] Mr. Acconci's robust ego against Mr. Tuazon's raw and fragile subjectivity." <ref>[https://www.nytimes.com/2010/04/16/arts/design/16galleries-005.html "Oscar Tuazon: ‘My Flesh to Your Bare Bones’," New York Times, April 16, 2010]</ref>
==Personal life== In 2013, he moved from France to the [[Silver Lake, Los Angeles|Silver Lake]] neighborhood of Los Angeles with his three children and wife Dorothée Perret, a former editor at [[Purple (magazine)|Purple Magazine]] who now helms the art magazine "Paris, LA."<ref>[http://www.wmagazine.com/people/2013/11/dorothee-perret/ "Dorothée Perret: Saint Laurent designer Hedi Slimane isn’t the only French expat to put down roots in Los Angeles," W Magazine, November 21, 2013]</ref><ref>[http://www.sightunseen.com/2012/01/oscar-tuazon-artist-and-dorothee-perret-editor-2/ "At Home With Oscar Tuazon, artist, and Dorothée Perret, editor," Sight Unseen, January 25, 2012]</ref>
== Exhibitions== ; 2007<ref>[http://www.saatchigallery.com/artists/oscar_tuazon.htm?section_name=shape_of_things Saatchi Gallery Artists Page for Tuazon]</ref> * ''Where I lived and what I lived for'', Palais de Tokyo, [[Paris]] * ''I'd rather be gone'', Standard, [[Oslo]] * ''Oscar Tuazon / Mike Freeman'', castillo/corrales Gallery, [[Paris]] * ''Voluntary Non vulnerable'' (with Eli Hansen), Bodgers and Kludgers, [[Vancouver]]
; 2008 * ''Kodiak'' (with Eli Hansen), Seattle Art Museum, [[Seattle]] * ''Dirty Work'', Jonathan Viner, [[London]] * ''This World’s Just Not Real To Me'' (with Eli Hansen), Howard House, [[Seattle]]
; 2009 * ''Bend It Till It Breaks'', Centre international d'art et du paysage de Vassivière (France) * ''Against Nature'', Künstlerhaus, Stuttgart, Germany- ''Ass To Mouth'', Balice Hertling, [[Paris]] * ''Another Nameless Venture Gone Wrong'', Haugar Vestfold Kunstmuseum, [[Tønsberg]] (Norway)
; 2010 * ''Sex Booze Weed Speed'', (with Gardar Eide Einarsson), Rat Hole Gallery, [[Tokyo]] * ''My Mistake, ICA'', Institute of Contemporary Art, [[London]] * ''My Flesh to Your Bare Bones'' (with Vito Acconci), Maccarone, [[New York City|New York]] * ''One of My Best Comes'', Parc St Léger - Centre d'Art Contemporain, [[Pougues-les-Eaux]] (France)
; 2011 * ''Die, The Power Station'', Aldon Pinnell, [[Dallas]] * ''STEEL, PRESSURE-TREATED WOOD, OAK POST, OFFICE CHAIR, INDUCTION STOVETOP, ALUMINUM'', Standard, [[Oslo]] * ''America is my Woman'', Maccarone, [[New York City|New York]]
; 2012 * ''Shaman/Showman'' (with Karl Holmqvist), Galerie Chantal Crousel, [[Paris]] * ''Scott Burton'', Fondazione Giuliani, [[Rome]] * ''Manual Labor'', Galerie Eva Presenhuber, [[Zurich]] * ''Action'', Jonathan Viner, [[London]]
; 2013 * ''Sensory Spaces 1'', Musée Boijmans Van Beuningen, [[Rotterdam]] * ''Spasms of Misuse'', Schinkel Pavillon, [[Berlin]] * ''DÉPENDANCE'', dépendance, [[Brussels]]
; 2014 * ''I never learn'', Standard, [[Oslo]] * ''Alone in an empty room'', Ludwig Museum, [[Cologne]] * ''A home'', Galerie Eva Presenhuber, [[Zurich]] * ''Oh Brother'', Maccarone, [[New York City|New York]]<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.vulture.com/2014/12/19-best-art-shows-of-2014.html|title=The 19 Best Art Shows of 2014|website=Vulture|access-date=2017-06-30}}</ref>
== Prizes== Nominated for the [[Prix Fondation d'entreprise Ricard]] in 2009.
==References== {{reflist}}
{{Authority control}}

revision.text:
{{Infobox artist | name = Petr Andreevich Pavlensky
Пётр Андреевич Павленский | image = Петр Павленский.jpg | caption = | birth_name = | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1984|03|08}} | birth_place = [[Saint Petersburg|Leningrad]], [[Russian SSR]], [[Soviet Union]] | death_date = | death_place = | nationality = Russian | field = Actionism, political art | training = [[Saint Petersburg Art and Industry Academy]], St. Petersburg Pro Arte Foundation for Culture and Arts | movement = | works = Political art :
''Seam'', ''Carcass'', ''Fixation'', ''Freedom'', ''Segregation'' | patrons = | website = [http://politpropaganda.com politpropaganda.com] | influenced by = | influenced = | awards = }} '''Petr''' (or '''Pyotr''') '''Andreyevich Pavlensky''' ({{lang-ru|link=no|Пётр Андреевич Павленский}}; born March 8, 1984) is a Russian performance artist and political activist.{{cite web|url=http://www.rferl.org/content/russia-eight-who-have-taken-a-stand/27208063.html|title=Eight Russians Who Have Taken A Stand|first=|last=RFE/RL|date=25 August 2015|publisher=|via=Radio Free Europe / Radio Liberty}} == Early life and education == Born in [[Saint Petersburg|Leningrad]] in 1984, Pavlensky studied monumental art at the [[Saint Petersburg Art and Industry Academy]].''V. Martinovich.'' [http://www.belgazeta.by/ru/2012_08_13/society/24602/ Petr Pavlensky: «Pussy Riot was much lighter and less harmful than Jesus Christ's actions»] // www.belgazeta.by. – 2012. – Aug.13''K.Petrov'' [http://www.rosbalt.ru/piter/2012/09/15/1034599.html Petr Pavlensky: «Art Is Unthinkable without Experiment»] // RosBalt. – 2012. – Sept. 15 During his fourth year in the Academy, he took additional training at St. Petersburg Pro Arte Foundation for Culture and Arts ([[:ru:Про Арте]]). == Career == Pavlensky and Oksana Shalygina founded an independent online newspaper ''Political Propaganda'' in 2012, which was dedicated to [[contemporary art]] in political contexts, "overcoming cultural chauvinism, implemented by the government", [[feminism]] and [[gender equality]].''Own. inf.'' [http://artchronika.ru/news/19706/ New Site about Art and Politics] // ArtChronicles. – 2012. – December, 4 === ''Stitch'' === Pavlensky first became known for [[lip sewing|sewing his mouth shut]] in political protest against the incarceration of members of the Russian punk group [[Pussy Riot]].''A. Mavliev, K. Akhmetjhanova'' [http://spb.kp.ru/online/news/1204927/ Artist sutured his mouth in support of Pussy Riot] // Komsomolskaya Pravda. – 2012. – July, 23.''SobKor'' [http://ria.ru/society/20120723/707321040.html A Saint Petersburg artist sutured his mouth in support of Pussy Riot] // RIA News. – 2012. – July, 23. On July 23, 2012, Pavlensky appeared at [[Kazan Cathedral, St. Petersburg]] with his lips sewn up holding a banner that stated, "Action of Pussy Riot was a replica of the famous action of Jesus Christ (Matthew 21:12–13)".''SobKor'' [http://pravaya.ru/news/22782 Petersburg Peter Pavlensky sewed his mouth in support of punk parishioners] // pralaya.ru. – 2012. – July, 24. Police called an ambulance and sent him for a psychiatric examination; the psychiatrist declared him sane and released him shortly after the incident.''A. Matveeva'' [http://artchronika.ru/persona/pavlensky-interview/ Petr Pavlensky: «A simple intersection of a vertical line with horizontal is already considered as an insult to the faith»] // artchronika.ru. – 2012. – July, 24. The artist stated that he was highlighting the lack of regard for artists in contemporary Russia, saying: "My intention was not to surprise anyone or come up with something unusual. Rather, I felt I had to make a gesture that would accurately reflect my situation."''V. Komarova.'' [http://www.echo.msk.ru/blog/publicpost/916475-echo/ With widely sutured mouth] // Echo of Moscow. – 2012. – Aug, 6. On November 14, 2012, [[Reuters]] published its list of the 98 best photos of the year which included a photograph of Pavlensky with his mouth sutured in support of Pussy Riot.[http://blogs.reuters.com/fullfocus/2012/11/30/best-photos-of-the-year-2012/#a=67 Artist Pyotr Pavlensky, a supporter of jailed members of the female punk band "Pussy Riot", looks on with his mouth sewed up as he protests outside the Kazan Cathedral in St. Petersburg, July 23, 2012.] // ''Best photos of the year 2012'', Reuters. – 2012. – November 14, 2013. === ''Carcass'' === On May 3, 2013, Pavlensky held a political protest against repressive government policies. His art performance was called ''Carcass''.''R. Moshkhoyev'' [http://www.kp.ru/online/news/1431470/ In St. Petersburg, the trial of "naked artist" has started] // Komsomolskaya Pravda. – 2013. – May, 4. His assistants brought him naked, wrapped in a multilayered cocoon of [[barbed wire]], to the main entrance of the [[Legislative Assembly of Saint Petersburg]].''''[http://escap1sts.wordpress.com/2013/07/10/petr-pavlensky// Petr Pavlensky] // Escapist. – 2013. – July, 10.''A Stolyarchuk'' [http://www.colta.ru/docs/21554?fb_action_ids=538052092900753&fb_action_types=og.recommends&fb_source=other_multiline&action_object_map={%22538052092900753%22%3A260476320763609}&action_type_map={%22538052092900753%22%3A%22og.recommends%22}&action_ref_map= St. Petersburg artist wrapped himself in the barbed wire] // www.colta.ru. – 2013. – May, 3.''Own korr.'' [http://www.mr7.ru/articles/82932/ Activists explained of the naked man action near the Legislative Assembly building] // www.mr7.ru. – 2013. – May, 3.''Own korr.'' [http://www.ntv.ru/novosti/580516/ Naked artist wrapped himself in the barbed wire near St. Petersburg Legislative Assembly Building] // НТВ. – 2013. – May, 3. The artist remained silent, lying still in a half-bent position inside the cocoon, and did not react to the actions of others until he was released by the police with the help of garden clippers. This performance was awarded the Alternative Prize for Russian Activist Art in the category Actions Implemented in Urban Space in 2013.{{cite web|url=http://grani.ru/people/1866/|title=Peter Pavlensky, Saint Petersburg Artist|publisher=Grani.ru, Daily Internet Newspaper|date=October 28, 2013|language=Russian}} In her interview with [[Radio Free Europe|Radio Liberty]], Pavlensky's colleague Oksana Shalygina mentioned that a metaphor of the action had its immediate realization in the reality: as soon as the barbed wire was cut off, and the artist was freed from it, the same exact wire wrapped him back in with police, ambulances and numerous field investigators.''D. Volchek.'' [http://www.svoboda.org/audio/broadcastprogram/729654.html Weekly Review] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131110173616/http://www.svoboda.org/audio/broadcastprogram/729654.html |date=2013-11-10 }} // Radio Liberty. – 2013. – May, 4. Later, Pavlensky made the following comment about his art work:
A series of laws aimed at suppressing civic activism, intimidation of the population, steadily growing number of political prisoners, the laws against NGOs, the 18+ laws, censorship laws, activity of [[Federal Service for Supervision of Communications, Information Technology and Mass Media]], "promotion of homosexuality" laws – all these laws aren't aimed against criminals, but against the people. And at last the [[Blasphemy law]]. That is why I organized this action. The human body is naked like a carcass, there is nothing on it except the barbed wire, which by the way was invented for the protection of livestock. These laws like the wire, keep people in individual pens: all this persecution of political activists, [[Bolotnaya square case|"prisoners of May, 6"]], governmental repressions is the metaphor of the pen with the barbed wire around it. All this has been done in order to turn people into gutless and securely guarded cattle, which can only consume, work, and reproduce.: Dmitry Volchek, "Cultural Diary: On Good Friday», Radio Liberty, May 8, 2013''D. Volchek'' [http://www.svoboda.org/content/article/24978110.html Cultural Diary: On Good Friday] // Radio Liberty. – 2013. – May, 8.
===''Fixation'' === On November 10, 2013, while sitting naked on the stone pavement in front of the [[Lenin's Mausoleum]] on the [[Red Square]], Moscow, Pavlensky hammered a large nail through his [[scrotum]] affixing it to the stone pavement. His action coincided with the annual Russian Police Day. When the police arrived, they covered him with a blanket and later arrested him.AFP. {{cite web |url=https://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5i0205mTMZyKYJ8qWksj8E9IBkYjg?docId=cb5ad566-dfc9-43fc-9a09-1b50be1706bc |title=Protester nails testicles to Red Square cobblestone}} November 10, 2013. "A naked artist, looking at his testicles nailed to the cobblestone is a metaphor of apathy, political indifference, and fatalism of Russian society," declared Pavlensky in his statement to the media.{{cite web|url=http://www.newsru.com/russia/10nov2013/pavlensky.html|title=Self-harming artist Pavlensky nailed his testicles to the Red Square|date=November 10, 2013|work=[[NEWSru.com]]|language=Russian|accessdate=November 10, 2013}} ===''Freedom''=== On February 23, 2014, Pavlensky organized an action called ''Freedom'' in support of [[Euromaidan|Maidan]] and [[2014 Ukrainian Revolution]].{{Cite web|url=https://slon.ru/posts/67581|title=Тело как оружие. Почему Петр Павленский неуязвим для власти|website=slon.ru|access-date=2016-05-06}} The artist and his friends built an imitation [[barricade]] on [[Tripartite Bridge]] in [[Saint Petersburg]], burned tires, beat drums, and shouted Maidan slogans. The action was interrupted by Saint Petersburg police who arrested Pavlensky and his colleagues.{{cite news|title=Художник Павленский и Ко устроили "Майдан" в центре Петербурга|url=http://www.mk.ru/social/article/2014/02/23/989021-hudozhnik-pavlenskiy-i-ko-ustroili-maydan-v-tsentre-peterburga.html|newspaper=[[Moskovsky Komsomolets]]|date=February 24, 2014}}{{cite news|title=Петр Павленский устроил "майдан" в центре Петербурга|url=http://www.fontanka.ru/2014/02/23/004/|newspaper=Fontanka|date=February 23, 2014}}{{cite news|title=Петр Павленский зажег покрышки у Спаса-на-Крови в поддержку Майдана|url=http://www.spb.aif.ru/politic/action/1111269|newspaper=[[Argumenty i Fakty]]|date=February 23, 2014}} On February 25, 2014, Dzerzhinsky Criminal Court stopped the administrative case against Pavlensky and his assistant Yaroslav Gradil ({{lang-ru|link=no|Ярослав Градиль}}) on the accusations of [[hooliganism]], and released them from prison. An investigation into Pavlensky's alleged violation of the regulations on political meetings continued.{{cite news|title=Художнику Павленскому простили поджог покрышек|url=http://lenta.ru/news/2014/02/25/pavlensky/|newspaper=[[Lenta.ru]]|date=February 25, 2014}} He was charged with vandalism due to the tire burning.{{cite news |url= https://www.theguardian.com/world/2015/jul/28/petr-pavlensky-artist-scrotum-red-square-interrogator |title=How Russia's 'most controversial artist' persuaded his interrogator to change sides |first= Ivan |last= Nechepurenko |work= [[The Moscow Times]] |publisher= guardian.co.uk |date= July 28, 2015 }} ===''Segregation''=== [[File:Петр павленский.jpeg|thumb|Pavlensky moments after self-harming. Moscow, October 2014.]] On October 19, 2014, Pavlensky cut off his earlobe with a [[chef's knife]] while sitting naked on the roof of the infamous [[Serbsky Center]] to protest [[political abuse of psychiatry in Russia]].{{cite web | url=http://slon.ru/fast/russia/khudozhnik-pavlenskiy-otrezal-sebe-mochku-ukha-1173405.xhtml | script-title=ru:Художник Павленский отрезал себе мочку уха | publisher=Slon.ru | date=October 19, 2014 | accessdate=2014-10-19 |language=Russian}} ===''Lubyanka's burning door''=== Pavlensky came to the first entrance of the Lubyanka Building, which is the headquarters of the [[Federal Security Service|Russian Federal Security Service]] on November 9, 2015 at 1:15 a.m. Moscow time, and doused the front door with gasoline and set fire to it with a cigarette lighter. The doors of the building were partially burnt. Pavlensky was detained after 30 seconds without resistance, and charged with debauchery. A few hours after the action, a video appeared on the Internet with an explanation of the meaning of the burning. The action is called "Lubyanka's burning door" according to Pavlensky. The criminal case against Pavlensky was opened on November 9, 2015 under the "vandalism" section of article 214 of the Russian criminal code. On November 10, 2015 in the Tagansky district court, Pavlensky declared: "I want my action to be reclassified to terrorism."{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/artanddesign/jonathanjonesblog/2015/nov/09/pyotr-pavlensky-is-setting-russias-evil-history-ablaze|title=Pyotr Pavlensky is setting Russia's evil history ablaze|first=Jonathan|last=Jones|date=9 November 2015|publisher=}} According to gallerist [[Marat Gelman]], the action shows Pavlensky's "obvious symbolism". "The Lubyanka door is the gate of hell, the entrance into the world of absolute evil. And against the backdrop of hellfire is a lonely artist, waiting to be captured ... Pavlensky's figure at the door of the FSB in flames - very important symbol for today's Russia, both political and artistic."{{cite web|url=http://www.interpretermag.com/russia-update-november-10-2015/|title=Russia Update: FSB Seals Entrance of Lubyanka as Artist Pavlensky Awaits Determination of His Case|publisher=}} On 8 June 2016, the Moscow criminal court declared Pavlensky guilty and sentenced him to a fine of 500,000 rubles.{{cite web | url=https://meduza.io/news/2016/06/08/pavlenskiy-prigovoren-k-shtrafu-v-500-tysyach-rubley-za-podzhog-dveri-fsb | title=Павленский приговорен к штрафу в 500 тысяч рублей за поджог двери ФСБ | publisher=meduza.io | accessdate=8 June 2016}} On 13 August 2016, Pavlensky gave a lecture in Odessa, Ukraine which ended with the inebriated Ukrainian journalist and screenwriter [[Vladimir Nestrenko]] instigating a fight that ended with his stabbing one of two security guards who tried to subdue him. The second of the two security guards suffered a fatal heart attack after the incident.{{cite news|last1=Davidzon|first1=Vladislav|title=Russian Conceptual Artist Petr Pavlensky Gives Sensational Lecture On Violent Political Art, Evening Ends With Lethal Brawl|url=http://odessareview.com/russian-conceptual-artist-petr-pavlenskys-gives-sensational-lecture-violent-political-art-evening-ends-lethal-brawl/|accessdate=16 August 2016|agency=The Odessa Review}} === Sexual assault allegations and leaving Russia for France === In the beginning of 2017, Pavlensky received asylum in France, after he fled Russia with his partner Oksana Shalygina and their children amid allegations of sexual assault. Pavlensky denied the allegations and said the investigation was politically motivated. Media in Russia reported that a young actress from Moscow theatre "Teatr.doc" had accused Pavlensky of sexually assaulting her. {{Cite web |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2017/jan/17/radical-protest-artist-pyotr-pavlensky-flees-from-russia-to-france#img-1 |title=Radical protest artist Pyotr Pavlensky flees from Russia to France |date=2017-01-17 |access-date=2017-10-16}} === Bank of France === On 16 October 2017, Pavlensky was arrested in Paris after setting on fire the entrance of an office of the [[Bank of France]], located on the [[Place des Victoires]] in Paris.{{Cite web |url=https://sg.news.yahoo.com/exiled-russian-artist-torches-central-bank-branch-paris-114547388.html |title=Exiled Russian artist torches central bank branch in Paris |date=2017-10-16 |access-date=2017-10-16}} He was charged with property damage, together with his partner Oksana Shalygina. He was initially detained in a psychiatric unit, until a judge ordered him to be placed in pretrial detention.{{Cite web |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/10/19/arts/pyotr-pavlensky-paris-fire.html |title=Russian Artist Is Charged Over Fire at Central Bank Building in Paris |last=Codrea-Rado |first=Anna |date=2017-10-19 |access-date=2017-10-19}} == Projects and actions == * 2012 – Action ''Stitch''. In front of [[Kazan Cathedral, St. Petersburg]]. * 2013 – Action ''Fixation''. [[Red Square]], Moscow. * 2013 – Action ''Carcass''. In front of [[Mariinsky Palace]], [[Saint Petersburg]]. * 2014 – Action ''Freedom''. On Little Konushennaya bridge * 2014 – Action ''Segregation''. On the wall outside the Serbsky Institute of Psychiatry in Moscow. * 2015 – Action ''Lubyanka's burning door''. On the door of [[FSB (Russia)|Federal Security Service]] in Moscow.{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-34764044|title=Russian activist sets fire to FSB Lubyanka door|publisher=}} * 2017 – Unnamed action. At the entrance of an office of the [[Bank of France]]. == Group art exhibitions == In 2012, Pavlensky participated in the alumni and students art exhibition ''Oculus Two'' organized by Pro Arte Foundation.{{cite web|url=http://www.proarte.ru/events/oculus-dva-vystavka-molodykh-khudozhnikov-fonda-pro-arte|title=Oculus Two: Exhibition of Young Artists of Pro Arte Foundation|publisher=St. Petersburg Pro Arte Foundation for Culture and Arts, Russia |language=Russian}} In 2013, in front of the [[Hermitage Museum|State Hermitage Museum]] in Saint Petersburg, he organized a street art exhibition ''Ghosts of Identity'', which came as a project of his ''Political Propaganda'' periodical. == Awards == He was awarded the [[Václav Havel Prize for Creative Dissent]] in 2016. The Prize was later withdrawn after Pavlensky announced his intention to dedicate it (and its monetary award) to an insurgent group and then explicitly endorsed the use of violence as a valid method to combat government oppression.{{cite web|url=https://humanrightsfoundation.org/programs/hrf-programs/2016-laureates|title=2016 Laureates|date=2016|publisher=Human Rights Foundation}} Pavlensky was also nominated for Russia's "Innovation" art prize in 2016, but was later barred by the National Centre for Contemporary Art on the grounds that he had broken the law, prompting four members of the jury to leave in protest. {{cite web|url=https://www.academia.edu/24289908/Individual_agents_of_change_and_state_response_Performance_art_and_its_impact_in_contemporary_Russia|title=Individual agents of change and state response: Performance art and its impact in contemporary Russia|date=2016|publisher=Aliide Naylor}} == References == {{reflist|30em}} == External links == * [http://politpropaganda.com/ Political Propaganda], online magazine, in Russian. * [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=dfO4i8g_Uus Video of the action "Stitch"], 07. 23.2012. * [http://tvrain.ru/articles/sadovye_nozhnitsy_i_odejalo_kak_piterskie_politsejskie_vynimali_obnazhennogo_hudozhnika_iz_koljuchej_provoloki_video-342684/ Video of the action ''Carcass''] TV Channel ''Rain'', March 5, 2013, in Russian. * [http://panoramamix.tumblr.com/post/66672906745/pyotr-pavlenski-genital-fixation-on-the-red-square Animated Gif of the action "Nail" or "Fixation"] November 11, 2013, Red Square, Moscow. * [https://vimeo.com/45451906 «What to Do?», theatrical performance «Russian Woods» with Petr Pavlensky starring], 42 min, in Russian. * [http://echo.msk.ru/programs/oni/1066996-echo/ One hour broadcast ''They'' with Petr Pavlensky] TV Channel, ''Echo of Moscow'', in Russian. * [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=NIcjV2MyFtI Lecture on political art, given by Petr Pavlensky in [[Bergen]], Norway on September 9, 2013], in Russian. * [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=N-2VIu0HDA0 Video of art exhibition «Ghosts of Identity»], September 21, 2013, in Russian. * D. Zykov. [http://grani.ru/Politics/Russia/activism/m.221013.html Video of action ''Nail'']. ''Artist Petr Pavlensky nailed his testicles to the cobblestone of Red Square'', Grani.ru, October 11, 2013. * [http://rbth.com/society/2014/10/21/severed_earlobe_is_merely_latest_scandalous_art_stunt_by_pyotr_pavlen_40775.html Severed earlobe is merely latest scandalous art stunt by Pyotr Pavlensky, Russia Beyond the Headlines] * [http://www.advojka.cz/archiv/2016/16/too-creative-dissident Too Creative Dissident] A2 16/ 2016 {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Pavlensky, Petr}} [[Category:1984 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Russian dissidents]] [[Category:People from Saint Petersburg]] [[Category:Russian performance artists]] [[Category:Russian contemporary artists]] [[Category:Russian artists]] [[Category:Political artists]] [[Category:Prisoners and detainees of Russia]] [[Category:Russian prisoners and detainees]] [[Category:Riots and civil disorder in Russia]]
